Console arrived a lot earlier in the day than i am used to, but thats the only plus I will give the shipping team. Like others have said, my ps4 was placed inside a box with air bags on top of it. Most damage is going to happen on the bottom of the box, conveyors, loading and unloading will tear the cases up very quickly. My unit was not damaged and I have been enjoying it.  I do wish there was a better lineup of launch titles for the ps4. I bought Shadow fall, COD and BF4. I am disappointed  with shadow fall because I loved killzone mercenary. COD is cod, nothing new. BF4 I've played very little because i need a friend to back me up and none of my friends bought a ps4,  They are too busy with GTA5 to make the jump.  Console is very quiet and doesn't seem to get very hot. Seen some videos on some shoddy thermal paste and it makes me wonder how mine is inside. i build pcs for gaming and thermal paste is very important to the longevity of the cpu. Also seeing that massive fan and the way it dissipates heat from the apu is a good thing. My pc can trounce my ps4, but it is about 10 times the size and only 2 friends play pc games.  Overall I am very happy with my purchase and believe I will enjoy my ps4 for many years to come.

Size:The PS4 is actually slimmer than the PS3 Slim which is phenomenal as I tend to carry my console everywhere I go so it is convenient for me since its not clunky or heavy at all.Gameplay:The games play like a dream and it appears that the PS4 install majority of the game from the disc so there would be very little sound of the system loading from the actual disc.Apps:As of right now, there is a lack of apps so I can't play youtube although it can be done from the internet app from the PS4 . Pretty sure future updates would address lack of current apps available for the PS4.Best Feature - Remote Play:FINALLY able to utilize remote play from the PS Vita to the PS4. Every game that doesn't require the PS4 camera has worked so far on remote play and absolutely loving it.Overall - great system with some room for improvement.P.S. Unlike other retail stores, Amazon was actually reliable in honoring their orders once accepting my payment for the PS4 as I had horrid experiences in trying to acquire the PS4 from other main brand stores as they would give me excuses like something was wrong with my payment information or apologized for running out without updating their information.

The reason for this review is the poor packaging job Amazon did with my PS4. I have been a Amazon Prime member for over 5 years  and spend thousands of dollars on Amazon each year and the way the PS4 was shipped was by far the worst.The box it cam in was way too large and protective air pillows were only use on the side of the box. The PS4 was able to bounce up and down inside the box. One of the corners of the box was pushed in because there was no support on the inside.I got luck and my PS4 is fully functional with no issues whatsoever. Compared to my PS3 the PS4 is a big upgrade in all departments. The System runs much cooler and quieter, the UI is greatly improved and the dual shock 4 is also better than DS3.the only negative I can think of is the lack of blockbuster titles at launch.

Very happy with my new console.  I find the new Dualshock 4 controller to be comfortable and responsive, which for me is a huge improvement over the previous generation's Sixaxis and Dualshock 3 controllers.  My system runs quietly and hasn't shown any heating issues after about 12 hours of play throughout the weekend.I tried out the video sharing service with a short clip of Battlefield 4 uploaded to Facebook.  It would be nice to have sound with the video, but as it is the file sizes are small and the upload was super fast.  Editing was as simple as selecting the start and end points from a series of screenshots, and the entire process from hitting the share button, trimming the video, adding a comment, and uploading to Facebook took less than 90 seconds.All in all, I'm very pleased with my purchase and expect to get a lot of enjoyment out of it for years.
System works and is operational.

The PS4 is small, sleek and it kinda just works. The games look great, the OS is straightforward and, for the most part, pretty intuitive and the controller feels great in your hands.Where the XBO feels like a reimagining of the console, the PS4 is more like an improvement on the PS3 foundation and I kinda dig that. Everything is familiar to the point where I know where to look, yet still feels new and shiny. And the improvement over the PS3 are vast. Everything is snappy, you can get in and out of games in a snap and you no longer have to quit a game if you want to go to the PSN store or web browser or settings.I've ran into a few minor annoyances though. First one is the buttons. They look like normal buttons but are capacitive (I think). However since they're flush with the system I'm never sure if I'm pressing them or not because there's no feedback. The PS3 buttons always made some kind of sound when you pressed them and it's weird they didn't do the same for the PS4.Also it's great that they expanded the friends list to 2K, but it's almost impossible to manage a list with more than a hundred or two friends. It's an endlessly scrolling list and it refreshes too slowly.The controller battery is also pretty disappointing. And while the idea of plugging in some headphones directly into the controller so you don't disturb those around you when you play late at night is great, the max volume is pretty low. It feels like it's capped halfway.Overall, if you like games, you can't go wrong with a PS4. Currently I'd wholeheartedly recommend it over the competition right now, but only time will tell who the real winner is.

I, like many Amazon purchasers, was worried to turn on my PS4. I didn't think it would turn on, I was sure I had a brick. But low and behold, it turned on. But then, I was scarred to update my firmware to 1.50, the update which adds many key features to the system but after updating the system was working fine.I fired up NBA 2k14 and played a quick-game while it was installing. I then downloaded Resogun which downloaded in less than 5 minutes.This is a great system. The console itself is so sleek. This is a "sexy" machine. I also love the controller, super comfortable.

I wish it would support my bluetooth headsets - but it won't support any of them and doesn't look like Sony is ever going to add that feature.  Other than that, just like the PS3 with a whole lot less people in multiplayer games.  Hopefully that changes at Christmas time this year!
I still have to plug in to make sure it works and all. My review is solely on the look of it. It came dirty and the remote looked very old and worn out. Meh.. guess you get what you pay for.
Excellent

Ordered it Dec. 28, 2013 via Amazon, received it Dec. 30, 2014. Also purchased the SquareTrade 2-Year Game Console Protection Plan ($350-400), better to trust a 3rd party company(the "lawyer") than the actual company itself.Runs(loads/start up) games fast. The new, for Playstation, Party Chat is very very nice. Playing Battlefield 4 at 1080p(they say its actually 900p, but my TV only reads either 720p or 1080p, etc., not in-between) and 60fps is like butter, and the 66 player server capability is great!!My Turtle Beach PX21 Headset works with it, allowing me to wait for a wireless headset to come on-sale.My ONLY BIGGEST PROBLEMS ARE:--The controller's battery lifespan is like a 1985 battery, literally.--Why must Sony ALWAYS provide a cord for the controller that is TOO SHORT as if we're playing up close like PC gamers? Forcing the majority of us to buy a 3rd party extension cord(there different, the PS3 USB is a "mini" whereas the PS4 is a "micro" WTF!?!)--Sony has yet to release the HDCP reversal update for us YouTube uploaders. Personally, for me, the share button for Facebook is a waste, though I understand many people may like that.

this is by far the best video game console ever created. i bought the xbox one day one and havent really enjoyed the console much. it was only the variety of games xbox one had to offer that i saw as an advantage over the ps4. however, i was surprised at how much difference the controller made. the ps4 controller is also the best controller out there. it is almost like a ps3/xbox 360 hybrid controller. it looks like the ps3 controller yet it feels as good as the 360 controller did with the upgraded l2/r2 buttons and the thumbsticks. the grip feels so nice you dont have to squeeze the controller to hold it comfortably. the ps4 is also significantly smaller and more compact than the xbox one. the xbox one has an external power source with the utilization of the very space consuming power brick while the ps4 is lighter and it has an internal power source. the xbox one has better games, but the ps4 just looks better and has a better controller and in my opinion better value with the addition of a cheaper online subscription service which also includes better offers than xbox live deals

The Playstation 4 is a major upgrade to the previous Playstation 3. As an Xbox and Playstation user, it's easy to not hold a bias as I've seen the pros and cons to each console.Comparing it to the previous playstation three, the only thing I find that I miss is the ability to upload movies from a USB flash drive, but it's understandable with the new movie features, as Playstation wants you to use those instead.The controller is larger than the PS3 controllers, but it's not overly big, such as the 360 controller, in fact, I find it to be right in the middle and fit comfortably, much more than the PS3 did. The grip is better and I don't find my hands get as sweaty with them.The party chat, which IMO was really the only single thing that held the Xbox 360 above the Playstation 3, works like a charm and identical to that of the 360 (the layout is obviously different).The Playstation 4 has had a 0.4% fail rate, but that's expected with any new electronic device. That however is extremely good for the sum one million plus that have been sold.

For 399, you can't go wrong.  This has become the centerpiece of my entertainment center.  All of my blu-rays get played through it; Verizon's Redbox Instant, and Amazon Instant Video services are great; and I use the NHL App to stream live hockey games almost daily.  The last movie I rented streamed at 1080p and 5.1 digital audio without a hiccup.  The gaming graphics give my 2500 dollar custom PC I built a run for its money thanks to the massive amount of dedicated video RAM; my PC actually has less.  Every game will likely be 1080p.  I can't wait to try the remastered The Last of Us!!  It runs at about 1/3 the temperature of PS3.  The only real gripe I have is the required PS+ subscription to play online (only 49.99 per year, though, which is less than 5 a month).

So, there have been MANY conflicting reports about the PS4.  I came to share my story.  And as you can see, I'm a verified purchaser.First, let me address the elephant in the room.  Products sometimes fail out of the box.  This is true with ANY electronic device.  In fact, Sony seems to have been very good about making it right with those who have had issues.  Is the failure rate as low as Sony says?  Probably.  There's no way to know right now.  Rest assured, I wasn't going to review this at all because I was having such a good experience.  So keep that in mind.  If your Playstation 4 is working as intended, you are playing it.  You probably aren't going to write a review.  That being said, I wanted to take the time to review it so that it might ease some of your fears.  With that disclaimer out of the way, let me review this thing.First things is first, the device itself is beautiful.  It's sleek and much smaller than I thought.  A good bit smaller than my PS3 slim, actually.  It will fit right in to any entertainment center and be a conversation piece for years to come. It's that nice.Aesthetics aside, setup was a breeze.  Basically, if you have a PSN account, you log in, an update downloads, and that's it. You're ready to play.  The first thing you'll notice is that the user interface is a good bit different than before.  Things are a lot more streamlined now.  It is very easy to navigate, and also easy on the eyes.  Nice upgrade here.Games are why people buy this machine, though.  I have Battlefield 4, Assassin's Creed 4, NBA 2k14 and Call of Duty:Ghosts.  When you insert a disc, it begins to install immediately.  You can't start playing instantly the first time you insert the game, but have no fear, it only takes a moment.  Each games seems to handle these installs differently, but each is really elegant.  For example, the first time you insert NBA 2k14, it takes about 30 seconds, and the game loads.  Now, when you first start, you can only play a quick game, and there is no commentary.  That's because the game is installing WHILE you play.  That's so awesome.  After one quick game, everything was done and installed. Sweet.As for little things I've noticed about the user interface. Application switching is awesome.  So you are watching netflix, but want to play a quick round of Battlefield?  Double tap the PS button, and you are instantly in your last application.  No downtime or loading. It's instant. You are done playing a match, and now you want to go back to Netflix? Double-tap again and you are instantly back where you paused.  Amazing.Just to wrap up, I know this was a brief review, but I wanted to get it out there.  MY experience has been great. System runs cool, quiet and quick.  I have been having a ton of fun and really haven't even scratched the surface.  The only issue right now is a lack of games, but that's the way it is with any console launch.  As the year goes on, this machine is going to get stronger and stronger.  Are there issues with hardware? I'm sure. It's bound to happen.  But honestly, even if the number of bricked units is 1% worldwide, that would make this one of the most reliable electronic devices ever released.  If you are in that 1%, sure, it sucks. But don't let that deter you.  If you are a gamer, pick this up with confidence.I will update this review as the months go on, but again, after heavy-use for 3 days, this machine is a beast. Enjoy!

Fortunately my PS4 never has given me any major probs. Ive had it since launch. The games that are out for it now arent worth the upgrade but titles will get better later this year. Console has faster loading times, all games are in 1080p and you can stream vids. It still has a few kinks to work out. At times the console will just freeze up and i have to put it in sleep mode or at times unplug it. And at times the PS store doesnt load. The controller is comfy and you can charge it while you play. I just wish this console had more usb ports. It at least needs 4. Accessories easily take up these spaces. Also it needs a bigger hard drive. 500gb its probably enough to download every retail game from launch up until two months afterwards which isnt many. You dont actually get 500 of course. Thats a round off estimate. At least you can change out the hard drive though. I love the share button. So fun using it as a snap shot button for when people get crazy through streams. We got our PS4 delivered on launch day. After about two months of use, we have a clear idea on how this console actually plays vs. the pre-launch media hype. We have never owned a Playstation or Xbox of any generation, but we do have a gaming PC.Pros:- Great graphics in 1080p, good performance. The indie titles like Flower and Contrast actually show off its graphics better than Madden, probably because the big games were all designed with the older generation in mind.- Good selection of non-game apps. Not as wide a selection as the Roku, but certainly better than Apple or Chromecast. You can finally watch Netflix or Amazon Prime on your console in full 1080p glory!- Wide variety of power-saving and auto-shutoff options- Add your fellow PS4 users to your friends list, share clips or achievements, find each other ingame- Easy drop-in multiplayer gaming on the same console.- Gaming quality is comparable to my PC (not the highest-end PC ever, but pretty good all the same)Cons- Lack of games. But, this is always true at every new console launch. 2014 will see the game catalog start to catch back up to PS3 levels.- BUGS. One of the most annoying one is the wifi failing to work sometimes for no apparent reason. Only turning the system off and on can fix it. Also, turning on and getting nothing but a black screen sucks, especially since there is no hard power switch on the unit. You have to literally unplug the PS4 and replug it in. And there hasn't been an update from Sony in weeks. Can't separate their engineers from their bongs, I guess.- Can't play PS3 games! You'll have to hang on to your old PS3 for the foreseeable future :(- Hard to obtain. I saw this console being offered for close to $1000 just before Christmas.- Expensive controllers at 60 bucks a pop. Want a full set of 4? You'll have to cough up $180 plus tax.- Lack of same-console multiplayer options in favor of single-player FPS games. This is more of the fault of gaming companies, but still. When can we get our GoldenEye back?

There are so many things that I could say about this console, but I will just choose a few. Some people have gotten bad consoles, it happens, it's called DOA or Dead on Arrival. Which means electric currents went through them during shipping etc after manufacturing at some point. I got a good console on January 15th, which is the best time to get one since most "manufacture" issues are fixed.GAMES: Lets just say games are always going to minimal at any launch. We look at the PS4 and we see a small selection, did you buy PS+ or PlayStation Plus? Well look no further you get a free game per month when you are subscribed which is now required for online play, here is the thing Xbox One doesn't do the free Games, Like PS3 as more games become available, we get more per month. So far I have gotten: Don't Starve: Console Edition, Outlast (Really cool Horror game) and Dead Nation a zombie game similar to Diablo 3 on consoles. Overall the games are great for what I have paid for!Console: The console and the OS (Operating System) are really smooth, user friendly, and very slick. It's amazingly fast also. I can say it does lag at some times, but when you have a console with a new OS of course there will be issues which can be fixed in updates etc. Overall I have no issues with the system.

I ordered the console off Amazon within 2 minutes of it coming back in stock the Friday before Christmas.  It got to my house on Christmas Eve.  Booted it up, and I knew something was off.  It started in [Safe Mode].  Then went in to download the update, it didn't automatically install.  I had to go back to [Safe Mode] and manually install it.  With this out of the way I got my PSN account set up, linked with my FB account, then started to install NBA 2k14.  I walk into the kitchen and come back and the console was reset.  I logged in and boom it shut itself.  This turned into a constant cycle of going on and off again.  I was really upset.  Called Sony and they said they would ship me a new one once they received mine.  Called Amazon and they sent me one and my new console got here yesterday.  They shipped it before I had even sent mine back to them which was fantastic.Anyways, new console everything went normal, no [Safe Mode], just amazingly fast and smooth PS4, the Next-Gen is here.  Installed NBA 2k14 but turns out the disc was defective so Amazon is sending me a new one.  Since then I have been playing Assassin's Creed IV and it is a lot of fun.  I have also been playing the Killzone multiplayer demo and will probably buy that as it has been fun as well.Overall the PS4 is fantastic, very fast, very smooth, very responsive.  The controller is awesome.  Here is the part I was most impressed with.  I have a set of Corsair Vengeance 1500 V2 USB headset that I use with my PC.  Well I plugged these into the PS4 USB ports, went into the audio settings on the PS4 menu while ingame, and switched it so all audio went through my headset.  BOOM it worked I was astonished they were compatible because this headset had been dissappointing me by not working that great with my PC but now I realize it is my USB ports on my PC that are the problem.  With the PS4 they work awesome.If all you care about is gaming, do yourself a favor and get a PS4.  If you wanna run your media set up through your console and talk to your tv then get an Xbox one.  Both are great systems for there purposes.  Sony has really made a great comeback whereas Microsoft has gone in a different "total entertainment" direction.Can't wait for more games and even better graphics to come.

I've owned systems since NES and now to PS4 and almost everything inbetween, including all of Microsoft's offering UNTIL XBONE. Just to keep things clear, i have been a HUGE sony fan since PS1. But i've owned em all. Coming from a TRUE GAMING background originating from the PC, i can honestly say that im glad to see the PS4 in its current state. its truly a GAMERS console. sorry, but i dont need to talk to my console, nor do i need to wave around my hands like a retard to get it to do things. i have a computer and a tablet for surfing the web, and a perfectly capable box for my satellite to surf my channels. When i power on my GAMING CONSOLE, im doing it to GAME. My PS4 was a launch edition that had ZERO issues, and continues to exhibit zero. I love being able to turn it on, and play a game i want to play on it. Its the truest essence of gaming. So let me just start this review off by saying that I think that the PS4 will earn a 5th star eventually, but doesn't deserve it yet.A quick history: I am 31 and have been "gamer" all my life, but spent the last gen exclusively with an Xbox 360. After much internal struggle I decided to switch to Playstation for this generation because, generally speaking, Sony has more story-driven games and franchises than Microsoft, who tends to focus on multiplayer shooters. That being said, here are my thoughts on the PS4:1. While the graphical jump from last gen to this gen isn't as great as in the past, you can still see the benefits of the PS4. The Last of Us Remastered couldn't be smoother. The graphics hum along at 60 fps without the slightest sign of struggling to keep up. Really impressive. Can't wait to play Destiny with this thing.2. It is really weird upgrading to a new system that can do less than my Xbox 360 in terms of media apps. The same is true for the Xbox One right now, but it is a really strange part of this upgrade cycle. More apps are on the way, but be prepared to feel like your new console can't really do very much yet.3. The PS4 is surprisingly loud whenever the cooling fan kicks on. I mean, like old-school-Xbox-360 loud. Really disappointing from a brand new piece of technology.4. Playstation Now is still too expensive, but it is perfect for someone like me that missed the entire PS3 catalog. Hopefully we will see PS1 and PS2 titles on there soon. Really a great feature.And that's really all there is to say at this point. I am very pleased with the system, but it still feels like more of a long-term investment than something to get really excited about right now. Without tons of media apps, this thing is really only as good as the games you own for now. There is plenty to look forward to in the future (especially Playstation TV). You won't be disappointed with the purchase right now, but you probably won't be blown away either.

First of all, I'd like to state that I've owned a PS (the one is implied, considering I had it when it was only a "PlayStation"), a PS2, and a PS3. I have nothing against the Xbox. I just never wanted one. I haven't experienced the Xbox One yet--but I know they make good systems, and they (Sony and Microsoft) BOTH have had their fair share of hiccups.I stopped buying games for PS3 months ago. I hadn't heard anything pertaining to backwards compatibility, so I just assumed (correctly), that neither system would be. That's a downer for me. I'm sure they could've figured out a way to make the PS4 play PS3 games. I have a launch day PS3 (yup, it's still kicking), but I guess the later versions removed that feature. Anyway, the system looks I like the slanted portion of the body (although that's likely it is because it's something different in a world of boxes). It's sort of like if a PS2 and PS3 had a baby. You have the finishes of both systems, so you can actually touch it without getting prints all over the thing (unlike the PS3 I have).The overall interface seems cumbersome. I mean, I guess it is okay, but it isn't really something I'm into. There's simply too much going on, for my liking. That's just my opinion. It's user friendly, in terms of being able to go on FB and "share" stuff (which I haven't done). PSN didn't work for me when I tried it. I don't know if it was the load, or an update of PSN...but I'm only able to use it occasionally.There is a difference in graphics, albeit slight. I know a lot of games were 720p, but all the ones I have (Madden, AC IV, NFS, CoD, NBA 2k, and Injustice) are all in 1080p. The difference is noticeable; at least to me, it is. This is relative to your screen size. Mine is big enough to notice the difference between the two. The PS3 also struggled to process some of the later games. Although I didn't buy any, I've played some of the heavier games. You could, literally, hear the PS3 struggling to process them. The PS4, though, does it seamlessly. The Last of Us comes to mind, in terms of the PS3 struggling, but it isn't available on PS4.The game selection at launch was a big thing for people. I knew I was going to get it...and, frankly, so long as I get a couple of games I can play, it's okay--so long as I can't play through them and get tired of them before there's something else. This system seems capable.The Dual Shock 4 takes a bit to get used to. I swear, I still look for the start button when I need to pause it. It's the same shape, same concept, but it just takes a bit of getting used to. It should be relatively seamless, with time. The system is quiet, and fits well with my current set-up--so I lucked up there. I'm not implying it won't clash with someone else's set-up (in case that matters).I saw a lot of shipping woes. It was sort of unbelievable the shape some of the packages arrived. Mine came in a box, with the standard air bags, plus the regular PS4 box. Not a nick, not a scratch. Everything was in good order. I don't know if it was because I needed a (slightly) larger box because other items shipped as well, but my shipping was fine. It showed up, in perfect order and on time.Depending on what you're looking for, the PS4 might be it. I think I may have to play it for more hours, just so I know I won't get the same blue light issue...although some of those reviews are questionable. Regardless, I want to play it more so I can have a more informed review. I will update after that. At best, my review will stay the same (I don't rate anything five stars...something would have to be the best, most innovative thing, ever, to get rated five). Worst case, I will down grade it to below four.Here's hoping I don't have to downgrade. I hope this helps!
Good product, great service.

Love the console and the redesigned controller. Only complaint is the number of games that interested me at launch, but there are tons of games coming out this year, so only a temporary issue.I had a first gen PS3 which suffered from overheating issues. This was later worked out in the 40GB models but that didn't help me at all since I was going for backwards compatibility. I was a little worried about heat, but it was unnecessary. This machine has excellent cooling, and the rear fans have plenty of power to move that heat out of the system. Be wary of putting it too close to something though, because that will get hot. I noticed this when adjusting things on my UPS, so I had to scoot it a little further away from the outlet to give more room.One of my favorite things about this is the way you can multitask and switch from screen to screen or application to application almost seamlessly. I can be watching Netflix one minute, and within seconds check something in the Playstation store. Once that's done switch back over to Netflix with hardly any wait time.Live streaming isn't a feature I've used profusely, but it was a cool way to enjoy games with friends. We'd hop on a Skype call while I turned on the stream, and we'd all laugh as I'd fail a CoD mission, or get killed attempting to assassinate a target in AC4.Playstation plus for this machine is a must. Even if you aren't a huge multiplayer fan, the games alone make the annual fee worth it. Tons of new games and DLC each month. I was able to get at least 10 games free in the first 6 months that I've had this console. These aren't games that I'd typically buy for myself, but it was a cool way to get to know my PS4. Resogun is an excellent game which kept me entertained and showed me how great the PS4 graphics are.

You cant go wrong with getting a PS4 right now. Console launches typically dont have that great of games to show full potential of the system, but ill patiently wait a few months till something good comes out.I was worried about the integrity of my PS4 when I examined the packaging done by Amazon. The tape on the box was basically blowing in the wind and not really serving its purpose for keping my box closed....I coukd stick my entire arm into the box without even removing any tape....I can only assume the tape had not been sticky enough when applied so it just didnt stick.bubble air stuff was loosely placed in the box and the console was wrapped in 2 small thin layers of bubble wrap.I use to package stuff in a warehouse for shipping, amazon clearly needs to QC there packaging methods.
HDMI port is glitchy and the controller doesn't hold a charge.

I have the money to buy both XBox one and PS4, but instead I used the extra cash to buy a 1TB SSD for my PS4. If you are thinking of getting a game, I recommend Infamous Second Son. Graphics are gorgeous.

Came with a different color controller than the console, which would be ok except the right stick drifts sometimes and i can't control where I am pointing or what i'm doing. I would recommend buying new if you can afford it.
Love it. Still going strong.

The system has delivered on its promises, the increase in performance over the ps3 is definitely noticeable. Loving the dual shock 4 as well, the headphone jack on the controller is genius & the built in speaker adds a nice dynamic. The system runs very quietly & doesn't seem to get hot as quickly as my ps3 did. The home screen is fluid, & the ability to multitask gives a sense of freedom which was lacking in the ps3 version. The ability to organize the icons homescreen to your liking is all that's missing. Overall it's a solid system, however, I do get the feeling my purchase was premature. PS+ free games for the PS4 have been a lower quality than those released for PS3, i guess that can be expected for a new console. Also I do miss DLNA support more than I thought I would, hopefully Sony adds this feature in the near future. The selection of games is also not so great, it is improving as there are new releases coming out, but right now i don't get a sense of available variety. Also i don't like the parental control system, setting up parental control requires you to register with credit card information. As a customer who resides outside  of the U.S. not having a U.S. credit card & address basically excludes me from setting up parental control for a child account. This limits me to turning on parental control for all accounts or disabling it for all accounts. Also the names of the games are displayed when parental control is enabled.

The playstation itself was great. The delivery and hassle I went through with Amazon was NOT. When I received this the Sony box itself was busted and looked like it had been thrown down a flight of stairs. Customer service was a real hassle. BUT with that said I kept this playstation since Amazon could not promise me one before February (it was a Christmas gift) and it is still working great. I wouldn't advice throwing yours down a flight of stairs, but ours survived something similar to that while in its box.

Oh PS4 how I wish you weren't such a pain in the butt.First off lets get the good out of the way.Nice system, good frame rates, good graphics.Ok now the bad things:1. Loud as heck2. Form factor is terrible IMO. The Angles make it annoying to fit in certain places.3. Remote play is crap if you aren't 5 feet from your router or the ps44. Confusing "adding a controller" system. What do you mean pick a profile for the controller? My buddy just wants to freaking play fifa with me! (I get it now  but still its dumb.5. Power options don't make a ton of sense.6. Confusing menu system.7. Bluetooth headset don't work (really Sony?)8. Old racing wheels don't work (really Sony?)Anyways lots of little complaints. Its a good system that you should buy for a used price. Probably from Amazon as they seem to have the best prices.

As a Sony fanboy I have to say I love this system. I never considered getting the "other" box. I would have given this 5 stars but as of now there are not alot of games. Happens when you buy a system near launch. This system is small sleek and powerful. If you need any futher proof lokk at the screens from Infamous:Second Son.

After reading the negative reviews and knowing that I had my system preordered since June, I was worried that I would end up with a brick. I then became more confident that my luck wouldn't be good when my father received a brick (yes my 66 year old father is a gamer as well) 2 days prior.My system came Weds afternoon. I set everything up and got the blue light for a good 12 seconds. Then i took a deep breath of relieve when the "white light" came on.I have played it last few nights on avg of 3 hours an evening (i have been flipping between Contrast (free with PSN +) , Madden and Assassins Creed 4. So I have been putting it through its motions. Its shown no signs of wanting to overheat and ran cool.Looks like I am out of the water for the time being.Now for the technicalities...PS store is something to be desired. I understand its a new system to it will take some time to get some things up but as it stands now, not overly impressed. But it will come in time.The UI is ok..Not horrid like some have made it out to be. But its not great either. It is what it is. I do however like the direction its heading in. I see alot of potential as long as Sony keeps working on it.The controller..I love how it feels in the hand. not nearly as bulky as the PS3 controller, not to say it was (compared to the xbox) but in comparison the new controller feels lighter.  Its taking some getting used to without a true start/select button and everything seems to run through the options button. The Share button I haven't played around with too much as i have no desire to show my gaming skills (or lack of) to anybody!Overall i like the system, But hard to give it 5 stars until I see more for the system and what its capable of (and limits). I think 4 is accurate as it stands nowI say if you are on the fence on this or Microsofts system, i feel you will get more bang for your buck.  Just remember too, that other system had a few duds as well. So although it sucks to have a non working system, don't let it deter you from going with Sony because once everything is up and running, i think most will have a more enjoyable experience (not to mention have an extra $100 in your pocket that you would of saved!)

First off. I'm not a hater of ps4. The console is 5 star for quality. But I'm giving it 3 stars to give Sony a message. 500gb is not enough anymore. We're not living in the 90's where games are 1gb each. Games are massively huge now, 50 to even 60 gig not to mention the DLC you might want! That said, I will tell you I Filled up my console's hard drive within a month after I bought it at launch. Probably 4 weeks I had my 500 gb full. Mind you, out of the box, you're not even getting 500 gb like they say, it's actually closer to 400gb with the preinstalled stuff. Do the math, if you buy 5 games at 50gb each, you've done at least 250GB already. Want 10 games? Forget about it. Yes, we can free up space by deleting games we own, but ya know, how obtrusive and inconvenient is that? I don't want to delete anything off my hard drive. For me, honestly, 2 TB should be the absolute BARE minimum. Yes, we can upgrade our drives. But it's a pain. And the last two times I upgraded, I lost some game saves due to corrupted files. Sony, if you're going to release an amazing console like you did with the ps4, please do what's right ,give us a big enough hard drive so we don't have to worry.Make no mistakes. Awesome games, awesome console. Just no space to put them. Fail.

The PS4 is by far the best gaming console I've owned, it's fast and quiet the only way you'll hear it is to mute the TV, but even then it's not too loud. This one is a bit complicated.  Early on, I had a brief run in with "blue light of death," but it went into safe mode, reformatted the HD and (cross my fingers) no problems since.  Now, to the son sole itself.  Firstly, controller is amazing, and this from someone who always preferred the xbox controller for my big hands.  Esp. nice is the speaker within the controller, which gives out different audio information than that coming from the screen and makes for a very unique experience. Sorry that neither COD nor BF 4 took advantage of it.  So far, the only one that has is "Killzone."  Ditto for the touchpad, which is also interesting.  Other attributes?  Graphic very sharp, processor clearly shows it's power, and overall happy with my decision.  Already have a roku to handle all my TV and quite happy with how it works.  Xbox turned me off trying to make some sort of "all in one"....thing when I'd much rather just use my Roku on a diff input.  ANYWAY, so far, the biggest thing missing are the titles!  The processor has all this power and the controller looks so promising, but no game really grabs you and just holds you to the point of obsessiveness.  My advice?  Wait a few months for the "blue light of death" to get repaired and some great titles to come out and get a roku 3 for your media stuff. Praying I don't get a permeant "Blue Death" anytime soon.

The controller is such an improvement from the PS3's controller. Not that the PS3's controller was that bad, the PS4 controller just fits in your hand better. The user interface of the PS4's dashboard is very simple and quick. You can be in game and in a second, be scrolling through your trophies. This is the console to get. Its only a matter of time before more great sony exclusive games come onto the playing field, so now is a great time to buy a PS4.
Thanks, the product was just what I wanted. Keep up the great work!

I am a happy gamer so far. I love the design of this console, and it looks great standing next to my PS3. Background download and INSTALL is a beautiful thing lol. I may never download anything on PS3 again. I remember leaving the PS3 on overnight to get DC Universe Online a few years ago. On PS4 it downloaded and installed within a few hours, while I was playing other games. And I was able to hop right in where I left off on the PS3 version, even though I hadn't played it in over a year. No staring at the screen, waiting for updates. Flower looked amazing on PS3 when it came out, but Wow... absolutely stunning on PS4. The comparison videos do not do it justice. I've got a fairly large TV (73") and tend to look for details and flaws in graphics. Killzone looks good, Assassin's Creed 4 looks ok, but usually launch titles aren't the best graphically, so no worries. I'm not big on most of the PS4's social features, but I actually enjoy watched others players stream their games, as that has helped me decide on a few games I was on the fence about. I didn't think to charge the controller the first night (after about 4 hours of play), so Saturday morning I got the notification that the controller needed to be charged. Seemed a bit soon, but I just set the Vita as controller 1 and played Contrast and Blacklight with no problems. Remote Play also works great, so far I played Resogun and Warframe on the Vita. I'm in a 2000 square foot house, and there was only one area (living room) that I got connection errors. I really like the new controller, it feels great, looks great, but the battery life is a bit short. Also, I don't like the fact that I can't use my Sony 7.1 wireless headset with this console, but I've got a halfway decent wired headset I plug in to the controller. The included mono headset is a joke. Overall, I'm happy with the system, but I look forward to future firmware updates that will hopefully add features and compatibility.

This console is great. Everything works quick on it, from downloads to installs to loading. It is small, quiet, and doesn't seem to generate a lot of heat. The only problem I  can notice with it, is the battery on the controller seems relatively small; I've used it for a week now and two controllers have required recharging.I'm not going to dock any stars but shipping from amazon was pretty poor on amazon's part. I could see why so many ps4 systems were having problems, the box they shipped them in could easily have fit 2.5 or 3 consoles. And on top of that, the air pillows for packing were put on top and to the side of the system as opposed to around the product. With the fragility of electronics like this, this seems like it was quite a poor way of doing it as the system would absorb all the shocks and bumps during shipping rather than the bubble wrap. My system was fine, but the ps4 box was very scuffed and scratched on the bottom.

No problems, very impressive.  Received mine today and set everything up, installed the update and the system seems to be working fine.  Played a downloaded game for an hour or so.  Will update the review if anything changes, but all is good right now.  I was really nervous because of the reports of problems, so I was extra careful and inspected the HDMI plugs and port when I was setting up, and also used a LAN connection, rather than wireless.  As most have reported, the graphics are spectacular, and I love the new controller (especially because I can plug in my fancy earphones). Comes with a code for a 30-day trial of PS+ and another code for a $10 credit toward your PS wallet (downloadable games, movies, etc.).

I consider the PS 3 to be, perhaps, the most perfect entertainment device ever conceived. Sony's ad campaign from a couple of years ago was "It Only Does Everything" and that was pretty much truth in advertising. I used the PS3 as a multimedia hub for my household. A fully functional and updateable Blu-Ray player, with excellent DVD upscaling, and an unrivaled streaming device for Netflix, Amazon Video, Vudu, Hulu, PlayOn and others. A CD player as well, for rare occasions when a playing a physical disc was required. With the addition of a $20 bluetooth remote, this device was the seamless center of my home entertainment system. I expected the vaunted next generation console to possess the same functionality. Strangely this did not happen. While technically, the PS 4 can still do most of those things, it does so quite unspectacularly and with an interface so clunky that I have been forced to leave my PS3 connected.

The system is worth the entry price based off the launch lineup alone.  Killzone: Shadowfall and Resogun are easy choices to buy at launch not to mention the criminally underrated Knack.  Games like inFamous: Second Son, Watch Dogs, Drive Club, and Destiny are due in 2014 so don't expect a post-launch drought.  Sony got it right with this system.
My hdmi port seems to be damaged so system is down.

Things to keep in mind with this review.  I have both a ps3, a ps4, and an xbox.  Along with a Nintendo 3dsxl, and a PS vita, iphone, iphone, droid, all of which are great gaming machines in their own right.Pros*Graphics are absolutely fantastic.  I have the ps3 and the ps4 sitting side by side and by far the ps4 has the better graphics.*Ease of use - This thing is fast, like super fast.  There is a marked difference between loading games for the ps3 and the ps4.  and also that sweet little home button on the remote means that mutli tasking is a reality!  You can play a game, hit the home button and do other cool stuff without losing progress on the current game.  You cant have two games running at once which while not fun makes sense.*Fast- did I mention how fast this thing is?*The controller is much more comfortable in hand than the old one.*This goes along with fast but it deserves a separate mention; getting into and out of the PSN store takes just a few seconds!  On the PS3 it can take several minutes to log in and start looking at things, and it takes way to long to just get back out to the homescreen.Cons*backwards compatibility - I have lots of games for the ps3 that I really wish would work with the ps4. As a gaming machine, the Playstation 4 is a wonderful piece of hardware. The graphics are great, and will only get better in time. The Dualshock 4 is a tremendous improvement over the Dualshock 3 in a lot of ways, and anyone familiar with the XMB on the PS3 or PSP should get the hang of the new OS pretty easily. It has some cool features, like the ability to snap back and forth between whatever game you are playing and whatever else you want to do, from looking at your trophies to playing with the web browser.The remote play function with PS Vita is absolutely amazing if you own one, I have a terrible internet connection and it runs smoothly even for me. It's a great option if someone else needs the TV for any other reason.However, I've already encountered a number of issues with the system, most of them having to do with other features (or lack thereof) than playing games. For starters, not only was the ability to play media from a USB taken away, you cannot even download movies or TV shows you buy on the PSstore anymore. You have to stream them. That means if the PSN goes down for any reason or you are without an internet connection for any reason, you cannot watch your movies or TV shows you paid for, although the system does play Blu-Rays and DVDs. At this time the system cannot play MP3s, though Sony said that ability will be patched in eventually.Also, there is currently no way to pause downloads. That might not be a problem for people with a fast internet connection without a bandwith cap, but for myself I can only have one game on the list at a time, or else it would take forever to get anything downloaded. It is great that you can play games while others are downloading (most even let you play the game as it downloads, after it gets enough done) and in standby mode though. I just don't see how nobody though of letting you prioritize the downloads or pausing them while the system is on.Sadly, there is only a HDMI hookup in the back, which means if your TV doesn't have an HDMI port, you won't be able to use the system. I don't know why Sony would want to alienate customers who have to use component or composite hookups.While I love the Dualshock 4 for the most part, the light bar can be frustrating as there is no way to turn it off. If you are playing a dark game than the light can be seen reflecting off of the screen.There is currently no way to personalize your homescreen, so even if you don't use Sony's Music or Video unlimited services, there's no way to remove their icons. I would love to change the background from the blue swirls to a picture of my choice, like you could do with PS3, PSP, and Vita. Heck, even being able to change the color of the background would be cool.It's possible to fix many of these problems with simple software updates, and hopefully fixes for the light bar on the controller and the ability to pause downloads come soon. I'd imagine that themes for the PS4 homescreen will eventually go on sale too.I don't think a fix that allows you to download the media you bought on the PSstore to PS4 is coming, but hopefully I'm wrong.

It was all ok except the hand held controller did not work.  The only way we could get the controller replaced was to unhook the entire playstation, put it back in the box and ship it back to the sender!

I bought my PS4 a month after it was released and I have not regretted it at all. It's a step up from the PS3 and in my opinion, is slightly better than the XBOne although not by much. Below are my thoughts.Pro's:1) The controllers are comfortable to hold unlike the XBOne or 360.2) The Blu-Ray player is reliable and quickly loads movies3) The Ethernet internet is fast at downloading updates and watching streaming movies/shows4) The system as a whole is very reliable thus far and I have barely experienced at problems at all. Most problems come from the games themselves.Con's:1) The battery time on the controller is abysmal at best. I play maybe 30 minutes a day and a full charge might last me 3 days at best (1.5 hour total gameplay) before I have to recharge it. I bought an extra controller so I could just swap out in a hurry. This has been a constant problem since the PS4 was released.2) Games are slow being released but that is expected of every new system.3) The hardware is at least 2 generations or more behind current limits but again, that's typical for consoles. Both the PS4 and XBOne were dated technology before either was released.
Will occasionally die randomly so I have to do a power reset in order to put it in working order again.
I just love playing Diablo 3 on my PS4. I just love watching Hulu on it. It's pretty much all that I do.

What else can be said about the Playstation 4 that hasn't already been said by countless video game websites by now? Before I begin my product review, I will start with an Amazon Disclaimer: I purchased this product new through Amazon at launch, so I can't share any insight on whether this particular *current* listing is selling refurbished/used/etc items by now or not - which some reviews seem to imply.  That being said though, my system is still working flawlessly, and the PS4 is an extremely powerful machine.If you're a gamer and looking for the best current gen system, you'd be hard pressed not to go with Sony this time around!  And this comes from a video game aficionado who's been gaming since I could hold a controller, and a (still) hardcore Xbox 360 user.GREAT GAMES = Sony has always been a quality first party company and always provides some awesome system exclusives.  "God of War", "The Last of Us", "Bloodborne", "Uncharted".  And probably what is showing some of the most promise?  Sony's indie games collection.  There are some incredible, exclusive gems in their online store, which make games genuinely fun and simple again.  Forget the flash, these are games you can get lost in for hours.  Many third party companies have noticed the changing of the guard as well, and began to hop on board with Sony for exclusives or timed-releases for their games.  And if you don't believe me, check out E3 2015 for how many third parties are receiving Sony's backing and vice versa.  The games collection for PS4 and Xbox One will (for the most part) always be very similar, but now is the time to make the purchase.  There are some fantastic Triple-A titles finally available and more coming soon.GREAT SERVICE = Sure, Sony and Microsoft have had some issues with their online servers, but nothing is perfect.  Playstation Plus is a really fun online service, and is finally up there with Xbox Live.  One of the best features about the PS4 too is the PS NOW service.  For a tiny fee, you can now stream PS3 classic games all you want!  And PS NOW is getting new games and being improved constantly.  While Sony is still perfecting all their additional services, there is great promise with PS Plus, PS Now, and PS Vue.  The good news is that Sony has finally competed with Microsoft with their customer service, and shows no signs of stopping the improvements.POWERFUL CONSOLE = The PS4 is a beast, just as is it's competition, the Xbox One.  HOWEVER - Playstation 4 still has the more powerful graphics card, and while the PS4 only has a slight visual edge right now; there is a day forthcoming where Sony can potential run away with it.  With 4K becoming more popular, this could potentially be where you will notice huge graphic rendering changes.  Bare in mind that PS4 offers a very consistent and solid 1080p experience, while Xbox One mostly upscales the graphics.  As a recent purchaser of a 4K television, I can say first hand the gaming experience with one connected to your PS4 is mind blowing!CONS = Still not as good of an all around media/entertainment device as the Xbox One.  Sony is improving their services though, incorporating live television services, streaming for movies and audio (finally), etc.  But Xbox One came out with this at launch and therefore has the leg up on Sony right now.  Another thing Microsoft has going for it is the Kinect.  Sony just won't be able to match things the Kinect can do.  In Sony's defense, the highly anticipated virtual reality peripheral Project Morpheus is to be released in 2016, and that could be as revolutionary for Sony as the Kinect was for Microsoft.Bottom line, if you're a gamer you are going to love either the Playstation 4 or the Xbox One.  However, I can't see any reason not to purchase a PS4 alongside whatever other console you may have (Wii U, Xbox 360, etc).  You are going to get an incredible gaming experience, and with their streaming service finally becoming competitive, it's becoming an amazing entertainment and media center as well.  The games (especially those phenomenal indies!) however are what's making Sony run away with the console wars this time around, just as they did with the Playstation 2.  Going back to their roots, and for good reason!EDITOR'S NOTE: To the trolls down voting every 5-star review for no reason: the PS4 retail price has recently dropped by $50, so maybe you can ask your parents to get it for you now so you can get off Amazon for a change.

I'm gonna go Good/Bad/Good/Bad.Good console but the UI is crap. Crap sprinkled with garbage. We should have the option to turn off that annoying home screen music too. Still, I don't regret it at all. PS Plus has wonderful games and They added a Crunchyroll app early on, which XB1 still doesn't have. Then again XB1 has a Youtube app (Hint Hint Sony). The Packaging was also terrible, when compared to the immaculate box the XB1 came in. Obviously the Blu-Ray player is Top Notch. The battery life on controllers is the worst I've ever seen, FIX THIS SONY! Or at least put a better one on the market (a couple hours is UNACCEPTABLE). The Ability to rent games is Epic, though the prices are inflated for better games. There should be a standard price IMO. Way better selection than on XB1. But the PSN area is not pretty to look at...X-bar was better than this (I guess that's UI again, but it really is bad).The Specs are better than XB1. Not enough to make a difference in any game I've seen, but XB1 should have went with the better RAM, Good decision here by SONY. The Camera is crap in my opinion, but you don't have to buy it (This did not influence my review, just saying). Also, having to download, THEN apply updates for the console/games is tedious and unnecessary. I can see why some people would want it, but there should be an option to just DO IT. HDD size is way too small, both systems did this. Look at the size of install files. Especially Destiny. No way that's gonna be viable.The new lending system is cool, playing a game a friend owns with them. One negative comment about that though, no saved progress is LAME as hell. How about locking saves, giving you the option of buying the game later?Basically if you're a Sony fan, you'll love this system anyway. Anybody else, you'll still like it alot. Far from perfect so far, but if/when they address my gripes I'll update my rating. Fixing the UI alone would probably change it to a 5.

the ps4 is a powerhouse for the 1st time I can run battlefield just like I do on my pc and being able to go into the main menu and browse catch up with friends or download something without shutting down the game you are playing is great just press the ps button do what you have to do then click the game again and its right where you left off and if you're playing online it continues until you come back into the game ,sharing is a breeze and luckily I have not had the issues of some users I see with ps4 & bf4 issues I see online I bought the day one edition nov 15 and no problems so I'm happy plus all of the free games you get via download with ps+ are pretty good no heat issues or noise its cool and quiet unlike my boosted oc radeon hd 7950 in my pc but I run the fan at 75% so its to be expected

I was worried with so many getting dead consoles from Amazon.  However, mine worked and it is great.  Many reviews will outline the features and such.  I will tell you one of the first things I did was upgrade to a 1TB hard drive to handle the excessive storage demands.  The process was super easy and took me about 15 minutes total (including software updates).  All you need is a screwdriver and thumb drive.  The process is easy and Sony has clear directions since they seem to encourage buyers to upgrade.  I recommend everyone do that right away, before you get too much on the original hard drive.Pros: Just about everything.Cons: Amazon packing really left something to be desired.  Also, having to invest in a hard drive right away stinks.  Since they don't support USB, you can't just put it off until you need it or you will run into a headache moving content to a new hard drive.

Great system. Small, elegant and powerful. OS works smooths and can switch between tasks like a modern smart phone. Love the games, F2P, cross gen (free PS4 Flower since I owned PS3 version, nice!), MMO (DCUO is Crackdown meets Everquest). My kids love Knack, I'm playing KZ. So far so great.

Received the PS4 on launch day and unfortunately had received one of the units that would not boot (blue light blink only.)  Numerous attempts to reach Sony (chat was busy or would drop, phone hold was LONG) over the weekend did result in some frustration and I was ready to ship back to Amazon.  (which was willing to accept and has always been easy to do) However, I decided to give Sony one more chance.  Monday I was able to talk with someone within 10 minutes and after some troubleshooting it was determined they needed to replace.  Sony overnighted a box for return with paid overnight return - long story short - got my PS4 back from Sony within a week (Thanksgiving included.)The PS4 looks like it will be an amazing replacement for my PS3.  Battlefield 4 and FIFA 14 are GREAT and COD:Ghosts is good for the same console co-op (Why don't more game developers understand that some of us still want to have friends over and play!)  The graphic potential of the PS4 can be seen at various times in the above three games, especially BF4.  The sound is great.  The new interface is VERY fast although it takes a little bit to get used to.  The update process for everything is easy (it basically can do it automatically for you.) Having to have a PSN Plus subscription was disappointing at first but then I picked a one year subscription on Black Friday at Amazon for $30 and have gotten my moneys worth in less then 10 days with the free games that I've downloaded and played.  The new DualShock controllers are a nice improvement over the last edition without changing too much (the light hasn't bothered us to this point.)  I've connected to the PS4 via my android phone and an iPad although i don't have any games taking advantage of the second screen functionality, it connected very easily and look forward to this being used.  I've used the ancillary apps for BF4 and COD:Ghosts on the iPad and they are decent but not game changing - yet!!  Looking forward to trying a PS Vita with this and AC4 and Killzone come Christmas as it appears that the AC4 app will truly add some nice additional functionality to the game play (map and navigation.)  Why only 4 stars?  I can deal with being unlucky and getting a "brick" as they replaced it - I just want to be able to play some of my PS3 games!!!  I hope Sony can deliver in 2014 with Gaikai?!?  Then it will be a 5 star platform!!
My all time favorite gaming system, amazing grapics, game play and online community, arrived on time, was in perfect condition, and great customer service!

Sony has reached out to the various developers and asked them what THEY wanted in a system before creating it. That alone should tell you how good of a system this is, and how much better it will be over time. This is a game machine, made by gamers, for gamers.

Very powerful console, interface is amazing, it takes a fraction of a second to go from any game to the PS4 XMB.You can quickly notice how stunning the new graphics are, even in games like Fifa, the difference between the PS3 and the PS4 is really really noticeable.The package even comes with an HDMI cable, which is really nice! So you have everything you need out of the box, no more runnings to the supermarket to get an HDMI cable.Also the new controller has a great feel in your hands, its a little more bigger than the DS3 but way more comfortable, the touchpad is really responsive.I can't wait to see Infamous 3 or Watch Dogs!
PS4 is a great console. I use it from netflix to gaming to listening to music. My only gripe is that the hard drive isn't bigger.

My ps4 arrived in great working condition. I swapped out the 500gb HDD with a seagate 1tb sshd for the boost in capacity and speed, and I'm happy with the result.My biggest reason for purchasing the ps4 was the remote play function used with the handheld ps vita. Games on the ps4 can be streamed over wifi to the vita, freeing up the tv for other viewers. This was perfect for my married life. My wife can watch her favorite shows(which I have zero interest in) while I pillage and plunder the Caribbean seas in AC4 (Aarrrrggh, matey!!!), all without having to retreat to a man-cave! It works with very few hiccups and very beautiful graphics! I was even able to successfully use remote play on LTE over 80 miles from home! Greatness!If you find yourself lacking the time to be able to play console games on your TV in your adult life, the ps4 (coupled with the ps vita) can reunite you with the joys of console quality gaming!

The console----------------ProsGraphics looks great, even for launch titles.Very small form factor.Twitch Streaming works very well.Upgradable hard drive.ConsCan get noisy when BluRay drive is reading a disc.  Fans seem a bit louder than my PS3 slim.Bundled mic and headset are really cheap.No HD stream option for Twitch.No wireless AC (not an issue for me, but may be for some people)HDD only 500GB.  If you plan on going all digital you'll probably need to upgrade the drive at some point.No support for external storage.No DLNA or MP3 support.The UI--------ProsNavigating the PSN store is much quicker.Navigation throughout the UI is very quick.  Even jumping to the menu from a game is fast.Viewing your trophies is much quicker.Integration with smartphone app is nice, lets you use your phone as a keyboard to input text.ConsNo way to sort or organize your games.No way to delete unused apps from the UI.No way to pause a download.The Controller-------------------ProsController is much improved from the Dual Shock 3.  Better sticks, better triggers.Plug headphones directly into the controller.ConsCan't manually turn off your controller to save battery while watching a movie.No way to turn off the light bar on the controller.Battery life on the controller could be better.Console needs to be in standby to charge the controllers.Charging cable is short.  It's not going to reach your couch. You'll need a USB extension cable.Final Thoughts---------------Overall I'm pleased with my purchase.  Most of my cons are minor issues that don't detract too much from my overall enjoyment of the console.  Some of the things can be fixed in future updates, but I have to rate the console as it stands now.I've played Killzone, Need for Speed Rivals and Resogun.  All look beautiful and much improved over the PS3/360 era.  I'd say the graphics are on par with my high end gaming PC.  I expect the games will only look better as time goes on.  Probably the best launch lineup for a system ever.  Wide variety of games, but very few exclusives.  A lot of the launch titles are on PS3/Xbox/WiiU, so there's not much of a rush to get a new system yet.  You can probably wait until Spring/Summer when titles like Infamous and Destiny come out.On launch day the PSN was down quite a bit, but that's expected when thousands of people are trying to connect at the same time.  I was able to load the 1.50 firmware on a USB stick and use the system despite the PSN being down for periods of time on the 15th.  Since then everything has been running smooth.  I upgraded to the 1.51 firmware via the console's updater and it worked fine.Thoughts on Amazon's shipping----------------------------------------My PS4 arrived via UPS.  The box was fairly large, about 3 times taller than the console's box.  The console was on the bottom of the box and there was packing air pads on top of it.  I'm guessing those are just there to keep the PS4 box from moving around inside the Amazon box during shipping.  It seems like it would have made more sense to put some of those air pads under the PS4 to provide some protection during shipping.  I know that UPS has a tendency to actually drop packages on my porch.  There was also a hole in the side of my Amazon box, right where the PS4 was positioned.  It looks like someone kicked the box.I'm guessing Sony's packaging for the PS4 should be good enough to protect it during shipping.  However, that box is very small, and doesn't seem to protect it very much.

This is the console generation where Sony got it's mojo back. During the last generation, it felt like Sony was largely playing catch up with the features of Xbox Live and the Xbox in general. The PS4 has eliminated the gap and shot slightly ahead in terms of raw technical specs. Virtually gone is the move controller and any integration with motion control. This console focuses on gaming and it largely succeeds.Pros:1. Big step up in graphics from the PS3.2. Overall better specs with a 500gb hard drive to handle increasingly chunkier game updates and downloads.3. The Playstation Network is finally ready for prime time. (even if it's frequently getting attacked)4. New controller adds functionality through slight evolution.5. Integrated movie capture mode that allows you to save the last 15 minutes of game play with the push of 2 buttons.6. Integration has been added to share your accomplishments via social media like Facebook and YouTube.7. Ever increasing game library.Cons:1. Hard drive could be bigger.2. There is no way to be online without all of your PSN friends seeing your online status.3. No backward compatibility with PS3 games.I would highly recommend this game console.

Nothing like I suffered through with my first four(yes four) 360 systems. The 360 works great now. The controller is very good, not great. The "option" button being in odd place being my main complaint. All the other buttons and triggers feel quite sturdy and their overall placement works well. So after a few months of owning my PS4 I only have one issue and that is with the controller. Other than that I like what games I have played  and am waiting for the PS4 game catalogue to grow.

I had my PS4 for about 4 days and then it became unusable. I was unfortunate to get a PS4 that crashed. But my review is still that this system is great. The few days I was able to play, I had a blast. The PS4 is an amazing piece of technology and extremely fun to play on. If you end up like me and yours breaks, call Sony Support and they will be happy to send you a replacement free of charge. That's what I did and I should be receiving my new PS4 within 3 days. They are sending me a box with overnight shipping so I can send the broken PS4 back. They put overnight shipping on that and once that gets back, they will send the new PS4 to me also with overnight shipping. The system is new and of course there will be some that have bugs or become unusable. I chose not to write a bad review because I understand that these things happen with new technology. The PS4 may have a few bugs varying by console to console, but it is still the best gaming system I've ever had the privilege to play on. Just because you may get a system that breaks, that should not change your opinion of the console. Sony is great about keeping their customers satisfied. Like I said, they will send you back a brand new console for absolutely no cost to you if you happen to get one that breaks.

This is probably the most comfortable gaming machine I've ever experienced.  It's quick and simple to get into the game you want to play and doesn't really require technical know how.  Streaming, sharing video and screenshots is a button press away.  The controller has a standard headphone jack that can work for ear-bud and microphone style communication or output the game audio.  Sony really has raised the bar for "gamer-centric" features.As of the date of writing this, there are only a handful of really meaningful exclusives so it is a bit hard to recommend to anyone who has a decent gaming PC.  I realize this is subjective, but most of the interesting games available on the PSN store are available on Steam and often cheaper and better supported.Another downside is that you must purchase a Playstation Plus subscription to use many online features of the games.  I have found this greatly balanced by the frequent Plus exclusive sales and giveaways.  A Plus subscription also allows you backup saves on the cloud and update games while the playstation is resting.  It's worth noting that these are all features that are essentially free on a service such as Steam.If you're looking for a simple and powerful gaming machine and don't want to fiddle with a PC, this is probably a great purchase.  For people with a gaming machine, it's likely a pass without at least one game that you really must have.

I received this on launch day and was extremely excited to start playing. I plugged it in, started it up, did my update, and was ready to pop a disc in. And then I received an error. It said my disc wasn't recognized. I tried another disc, and then a DVD, and then a Blu Ray. Nothing worked. Same error every time. I scoured the forums and found a few people having the same issue, but mostly complaints about the BLOD. Also, it seemed that a large majority of the people having problems had ordered the launch edition from Amazon like myself. I found a few troubleshooting tips and tried them all with no help. I called Sony customer support. I had to wait on hold for over two hours which was pretty annoying, but I wasn't incredibly angry about it since it was launch day. Once a representative finally came on the phone they were very helpful, walked me through a few more things, and then gave me no trouble about sending out a box to return it. They also told me I could go to my local Sony store to have it replaced and that I could just disregard the box they were sending me if I managed to have it done there. I was able to go to Sony the next day and they gave me no hassle at all, immediately handed me a new unit and apologized for the inconvenience. A few other customers were in the store as well with the BLOD problem, and all reported that their unit had come from Amazon. Once I got it home, it works great so far. There aren't a lot of exclusives available yet, but I have always been more of a platformer, indie, and JRPG player than shooter/sports/action, and that was my primary reason for getting a PS4 over XBone. My rating of the system is a 4/5, one star off for the current lack of games. However, I will never purchase a launch date console from Amazon ever again... if at all.

Bought it 3 years ago, still working fine and getting a lot of mileage on it. It's a great multipurpose console, so the gamer in your family gets some fun, your family can watch dvds/blue-rays, and you can watch hulu or netflix, among other things.

Had the PS4 for 8 months now and am very pleased.Pros:Fast OSGreat GamesGreat ControllerVita Remote PlayVita Second SceenPhone App Second ScreenCan Use App to buy games on PSN and download and install to your PS4 even when your not at home."Free" Games with PSN plusGood choice of Free to Play games.Finally has 3D Bluray functionalityCons:Most great games are either Indies or Remasters but more AAA games are coming this fall.PSN plus games are mostly Indies but there still great.Still alot of functionality yet to come yet like DLNA.Controller battery life isn't that great.I haven't had any problems with my PS4 and everything has been great. Still have a back log of PS3 games but I'm slowly transitioning more and more to PS4. Still waiting for more functionality that's more in parity with PS3 but more is added every few months.

I was holding off buying a next gen console until there was a game worth buying, and boy, was it worth it. I have not regretted buying this console for a single minute. Every game that I've played for it so far has been amazing. InFamous: Second Son alone totally justifies buying the console.

I love this new system!! Powerful, fast, and quiet.  The new user interface is easy to get used to, its very organized and simple. I highly recommend the psp vita as well, the remote play option is super cool and the extra options you have when combining the two are definitely worth it!! Also, a complaint to the game not console, is they change the trigger button from R1 to R2 and cannot change back by setting. The R2 design on this has a long travel (which might simulate the long travel trigger?), but the reset on it is way too long. You have to release the button to trigger next shot. This make pistol battle less ideal since you will constantly has "misfire" due to the reset issue, it is not the lag dude. I thought it was the lag but not.

A very impressive release from Sony.  Definite improvements over the PS3 both hardware wise and software wise. I found the PS3 user interface bland and not well laid out. The PS4 has improved that and it is much simpler to use and navigate around. Not perfect, but I suspect this will get better in future updates.The games look and play great. Sony push for Indy titles on the PS4 is going to be a boost for them. Playing games like Resogun and Contrast for free (if you have PS+) at launch is awesome. Killzone looks great.No real stability problems short of one lock up before the 1.5.1 update when I was installing DC Universe.  Had to pull power for that lock up. Holding in power for an eternity wouldn't fix things.  Powered off and on and was back up and installing the rest of DC Universe.Controller feels great, although a full charge only seems to last about 7-8 hours.  But that isn't terrible.Disappointed hdcp is active on games and user interface. Would like to be able to capture video over HDMI. Supposedly this is coming in a patch.  Also wish twitch streaming supported archiving on twitch for easy export to YouTube or downloading.All and all though the PS4 is a great buy if you are looking for a next gen console.

I have a friend who has had nothing but issues with his and is beyond frustrated. I was able to set ours up with no issues and got into the games just fine. You do have to pay to play games online now unlike with the past Playstations but a 30 Day trial of Playstation Plus is included and you get some free content as well.The graphics and sound are great and I love using the touchpad in game. The only issues I have had so far are due to Network issues as downloading games has been a pain. I got into Warframe yesterday and had a great solo and online match but was unable to get back in later due to network issues which also stalled my other downloads.I am sure there will be a few updates this week but being able to get four solid games for free from their online shop and the huge amount of titles in tv, movies, and games that you can get is great.  I also liked the ability to share my content to Facebook and stream with no issues.

Amazing. I have been with PlayStation/Sony since I was a kid and they never disappoint.

Soon as I got the package on the day of release that afternoon. I noticed that Amazon had cushioned the box inside to protect my investment which was a plus. The console itself I made sure to download the firmware and boot into safe mode to flash it to 1.50 before anything else. I didn't trust the OTA firmware update because the PSN was having intermittent connection issues. So far playing on and off since Friday I love the system and going back and forth out of game to the other services is fast.However what the PS3 has in terms of options it was taken a step back with the PS4. System options to the console is very bare in terms of customizing what you need compared to the PS3. When they say are going back to just gaming this time they really mean it. Not much in terms of multimedia except those apps that you can download from PSN or what you have as blu-rays. I'm sure this will expand as we continue to push forward.Why I gave it 5 stars is because for me I'm using this as a gaming device and not so much as multimedia that some would also use it as. Also to note that the fan can ramp up during gameplay so if you decide to purchase a PS4 later on when they are available, make sure you have a lot of space. The Dual Shock 4 controller feels extremely nice and the trigger pull on R2 and L2 are very light. My hand doesn't hurt at all unlike the DS3 when pressing the triggers for long periods of time.
