I have enjoyed video games since 1977, when my parents bought me an Atari 2600. I have been hooked ever since. I play it all from PC games, to Gameboy. I think that fanboy flame wars are just silly. I am a huge fan of the Playstation 1, and Playstation 2. With the Playstation 3 I felt that Sony got a little bit away from what made them the industry leader. Not that I did not like Sony's first party offerings, they were some of my favorite games of this generation. I felt that Microsoft had made more of a game machine, while Sony made more of a complex multimedia machine. Not this time, Sony came out firing on all cylinders, this is a game machine. It has amazing streaming capabilities, has a slick interface that is simple to use, and it has one of the most comfortable controllers I have played with.  Yes there is a lack of titles as of this writing, Killzone, Tomb Raider, Skylanders, Outlast, and Resogun to name a few are really worth playing. You can see it though, the potential, the graphic capabilities, this machine is the total package, and at 399.99 you can't beat it. Infamous will be here soon, along with MLB The Show. It's more powerful, and one hundred dollars less then the competition. It is worth it, right now. Buy it you won't be sorry.

I normally don't write reviews on amazon but I felt compelled to do so because of all the negative comments that the console has been receiving on various websites and the reviews here on amazon.  Let me start off by saying that I currently own 2 PS3(one launch 60gb and one slim 120gb), 1 Xbox 360 fat Arcade edition with a 250gb hard drive(jasper motherboard), a Red Mario 25th Anniversary Wii and a 3DS XL(so no I'm not a fanboy). I will start off by saying that amazon was quick on shipping it and making it worthwhile to have pre ordered it from them(better than standing out in the cold and potentially get mugged or shot for it).  Second the packaging was well put together in order to avoid damages to the console itself.  Now let's talk about ease of setup.  I can tell you that i did not have a single hiccup throughout the entire process.  Basically after plugging everything in and turning it on the console pretty much told me how to setup everything else without giving me any sort of error.  It just worked like it should.  And as for those who said that they could not access psn to download the update to firmware version 1.50 I cant' comment because my console was able to connect and download without any issues(in case you're wondering I set it up to connect through wifi which was also a very simple task).  So as far as experience in setting the ps4 I have no complaints as it was very straightforward with no complications whatsoever.Now here are the pros and cons of the console itself:Pros:1:  Quick to boot up.2:  Graphics look much more detailed.3:  You can play the game without waiting for it to install.4:  1080p at 60fps5:  Controller design is actually better especially for first person shooters.6:  Includes headset(which I personally don't care for since I don't like to chat with people while playing).7:  Can be setup standing if needed.8:  Cheaper than an Xbox One by $100 and $200 compared to my launch PS3.9:  No mandatory gimmicky camera.10:  User replaceable hard drive.11:  Easy navigating UI(User Interface).12:  No need to pay additional to stream Hulu, Netflix and Amazon Video.13:  PS Plus subscription will carryover from your PS3 and you still get a code for 1 month free in the box along with $10 credit for PSN(which is a good deal considering all the free games you can play for as long as you are a member and not to mention all the additional discounts you get when there are sales on PSN).14:  Can still play Blu Ray.15:  All games are now installed on the hard drive making the time to load quicker and at the same time no longer need to be worried about the laser on the Blu Ray drive getting overworked(  considering the fact that it is easier and cheaper to replace a hard drive than a Blu Ray drive).16:  You can access online social media(if you care about that since most people do but me personally don't have any of those accounts nor do I care to sign up for it).17:  Record your gaming sessions to display online(again if you care for that sort of thing which I have no interest in but a lot of people seem to do so).18:  Cheaper than a gaming PC and without the hassles of incompatible drivers and settings.19:  Game prices are still the same compared to current gen.20:  Sony first party games and exclusives that will never be available on PC or Xbox.21:  Internal power supply.Cons:1:  Not a lot of games available yet(but that's typical of new console launches).2:  Seems to run hotter than my PS3 slim (but about the same as my Fat 60gb launch PS3).3:  Needs more space for venting.4:  No backwards compatibility with PS3, PS2 nor PS1 ( although Gaikai is supposed to take care of that but I'm sure it will cost something).5:  Can't play your own music( at least not now who knows if a future update will allow it).6:  No more free online multiplayer gaming since you are now required to get PS Plus.7:  No longer can it be played on old school tube televisions with RCA inputs since it only has HDMI and optical for sound( but not an issue for me since I only have HD lcd televisions at home).8:  Small Hard Drive( considering the fact that some games can take up to 50gb but you can always make room by deleting old games or replacing the hard drive with a 1TB unit).9:  Still not as good as a gaming pc.10:  Games could be had for less on PC.Regardless of the Pros and Cons just remember one thing and that is the fact that anyone who is looking for a next gen console should be considering themselves as beta testers because not everything will work perfectly regardless of which brand of console you purchase.  No to mention launch games are always for the most part decent but not "OMG this is the reason to upgrade".  For me the number one reason to purchase a PS4 was so that I could play Call of Duty Ghosts and Battlefield 4 in 1080p at 60 frames per second since I don't own a gaming PC (which by the way is the only games I have purchased so far). So if graphics and gameplay is important to you and you have the disposable income I say do it. Now if money is tight just stick to the current gen since there will still be a lot of new games being released on the current platform so you'll still be ok.

Sony has delivered another masterful console this time. PS4 is the most sexy console I have seen. The console is small, sleek and beautiful. I actually liked DS3 and after getting hands on DS4, it is hard to go back. If you want to know all the features and tech specs, you should check out the CNET reviews. The PS4 is a great console. It has good graphics and sound. I love that you can listen to spotify while playing games. Also the shareplay is a nice feature, it allows you to give an online friend control of your second controller so they can play with you even if they do not have a copy of the game. Combine this with PS Plus and you get free games every month. The only thing that I have to complain about is the controller. It wears out easily, the touch screen is basically useless since 95% of games don't use it (it gets used more as just a regular button than it does a touch sensor), and the battery life on it is terrible. If you turn the light on the controller off in the settings or even just dim it it helps save the battery a lot.

It's a really awesome system.  I've had the ps3 since it first came out.  The graphics on the ps4 for battlefield are so much better than the ps3.  It's very realistic and awesome.  There aren't a ton of games yet for the ps4 but Infamous just came out and the graphics are said to be amazing.  Also a version of the batman games is coming out and its only for new consoles.  Need for speed is really cool and battlefield is the greatest.  Also Cod ghosts looks really good on the ps4, but I don't think much difference from the ps3.  Also the vita is fully compatible with the ps4 so that's going to be a lot of fun too.  And they are selling a ton of cameras for the system.  Oh the other great thing is the share feature, its a button on the controller you press and you are two clicks away from broadcasting yourself playing your favorite game to whoever you want.  you also capture a screen shot the moment you touch the button and it records your last 15 minutes of gameplay for upload.All in all, the ps4 is an awesome system and some sick games are in store for the future.

The console itself is beautiful. The design is simple, but elegant. It's size is perfect; maybe 50% bigger than the Wii or Wii U. It's nowhere close to the VCR sized Xbox One.The Dualshock 4 controller is a huge improvement from the PS3 controller; the handles feel longer, fuller, and more ergonomic. The light on the back of the controllers is an interesting addition, though it does seem to diminish battery life a bit. The touch-pad is another cool new feature, though it's a little awkward at first and takes some getting used to.The UI is pretty clean easy to use. It seems to be similar to the PS3 UI, but with influence from the Windows 8 style Xbox UI. UI response is instantaneous, and game load times seem quite quick. I liked how Killzone: Shadow Fall went straight to the main menu when I started the game (of coarse, that kind of game load will depend on the developers of each game) .At $399, the price was far more reasonable than the PS3 launch price.I never had a PS3 or Xbox 360 of my own, but I played on both consoles quite a lot. My last console buy was the Wii. If I had one of the primary last gen consoles (read Xbox 360 and PS3) already, maybe I wouldn't have shelled-out 400 bucks so quickly. But for someone with nothing better than a Wii, I'd say the PS4 is definitely worth the money.

The PlayStation 4 is an excellent purchase and a very well designed machine.  The first thing that will strike you is just how sleek the system is.  No matter where you place it, or whether you chose to sit it up or sit it down, it adds a bit of modern elegance to your entertainment setup.As far as the User Interface is concerned, it is another outstanding showing and a vast improvement over the PS3.  The UI is FAST, responsive and very easy on the eyes.  If you have a large-screen HDTV, you will really appreciate the new look of the XMB and how smooth the transitions are.The feature set is really too long to go into so I will list a few of my favorites:The ability to switch from game, to store, to Live Stream, to Internet Browser to Settings without having to quit your game.  The speed at which the system switches is incredible.Sharing Video, Live Streams, and pictures seriously couldn't be easier.  They are easily uploaded to Facebook or Twitter - and it all happens in the background - meaning you can upload videos or activate streaming without leaving your game.The graphics of the games are incredible and a decent leap from the PS3.  Even when playing games like Resogun; you keep withing for a frame drop or slowdown but it never happens.  This is one powerful calculating machine.Did I mention Resogun...PS4 comes with a 30 Day membership to PS+ which offers free games and is needed for some multiplayer games that aren't free to play.  Among those free games is a title called Resogun.  Stop what your doing right now and go play this game.... I'm not kidding.  Its like watching the greatest fireworks finale ever.So yeah this review is pretty basic.  The games are great, the hardware is powerful, the UI is slick and the design is elegant.

of course 90% of people who got bad systems will leave a bad review. but only 10% of people with good systems will leave a good review.sony says.4% were bad, not 4%, but .4% (though its likely that number is low). so 4,000 out of 1 million units. it happens, and believe anything under 3% is considered normal for electronics.The good:1) Size - incredibly small2) appearance - it looks like it belongs in any and all entertainment centers3) quite - lot less noisy then my day 1 PS34) great graphics! (though not a huge jump from the best of PS3 games) systems dont really bring out the best in games for a few years. the best ps2 game was close to the first ps3 game. but the latest ps3 games looks drastically better then the first ps3 game.the bad:1) less then a handful of games worth playingthe ugly:1) user interface seems empty (im guessing this will be changing with updatesUPDATE:At first the only game I played was COD Ghosts. I am now a halfway through Killzone and i want to let everyone know i think the graphics are much better then Ghosts. I figured that makes sense, Ghosts, was created to work on 4 systems, which means it probably isnt really optimized for any of them.where as Killzone was made and optimized for the PS4. Ghosts was Meh, BUT Killzone actually makes me excited for future next gen only titles. enough so, that i think i am going to sell my Xbox one. though i have only played Battle Field 4 on it, which is just like Ghosts, in the sense that it was made for all systems.

The PS4 fixes all the annoying things about the PS3, with fast load times, a slick UI, and most importantly it pretty much eliminates the constant installing and updating (it's done in the background now while you play).  It's a great game machine with plenty of great games already, with some really amazing graphics.One thing overlooked by a lot of people is that the PS4 has several of free-to-play games with more on the way.  DC Universe Online and Warframe are out now, with other games like Planetside 2 (and probably Everquest) on the way.  If you're a PS Plus member you also get the free games with that (Resogun is a must-buy even if you're not a member).  There's a ton of games in the pipeline and you don't even have to pay for many of them.If you have a PS Vita, the awesomeness gets turned up to 11, as Remote Play works really well.  Set it up and enjoy your PS4 games anywhere you have an internet connection.  There can be a bit of lag so it's not ideal for games like COD or Killzone if your internet connection is bad, but your PS4 game collection becomes a part of your Vita game collection too.

I think PS4 is a great deal as it's priced very reasonably considering its capabilities and graphics.Pros:1. Graphics- Most native 1080P games among all consoles, if you have a large TV, you will see the difference with upscaled games.2. Games- It's still very early in this console generation, but PS4 has the best versions of multiplayer games like Call of Duty and Metal Gear Solid V (higher resolution and better effects) and all the exclusives like inFamous and Uncharted plus many others. When you look at PS3 and Xbox 360 (I own both), you will see in the last few years PS3 still has great hardcore exclusives like Last of Us but Xbox has very few.3. Features- It doesn't force you to buy a camera, it's optional and will work with Virtual Reality headset Sony just announced.- Even if you don't buy PS Plus, you still can enjoy apps like Netflix, HBO Plus, etc; On Xbox, most apps are not usable without a Xbox Live Gold membership.- Remote Play lets you play most PS4 games with your Vita with even Internet connection outside your home.- Its UI is very smooth.- The controller is the best I've used among all consoles (subjective), has built-in rechargeable battery unlike Xbox's, save you money on $25 recharge kit or batteries.- It continually records the last 15 mins of gameplay, when you press "Share", you could choose a portion to share easily. Xbox One on the other hand has a delay in starting to record the gameplay after you ask it to.4. Playstation Plus- As mentioned above, it's not required for games like inFamous, only if you wanna play multiplayer games. It's $10 cheaper than Xbox Live Gold and comes with great free games like Batman: Arkham City (PS3) and the new Outlast (PS4) and Mercenary Kings (PS4). In comparison, Xbox Live Gold normally gives out really old games free.5. Design and Size- It's much smaller than Xbox One (which looks like a big and old VCR) and it doesn't come with a power brick, very important if you have limited space in your AV cabinet.Cons:1. Work-in-progress Blu-ray movie playback- Right now certain Blu-ray movies won't play (don't know why) and it doesn't support 3D Blu-ray yet. Hopefully this will be patched later, 'cos there's no reason why PS3 could do all these but PS4 can't.2. No DLNA support (yet)3. No backward compatibility with PS3 (same with Xbox One)- However, Sony already announced a service called Playstation Now to stream PS3 games, Microsoft hasn't announced anything like that4. Controller battery life- It's not as long lasting as the PS3 one, but now you can recharge it at night when the PS4 is on standby.In conclusion, this is the best console in market right now, you won't regret it!

I definitely love my PS4. The pay-to-play online with PS Plus was a little disappointing, but at least they give you a decent list of games throughout the year. There's a great list of games for the system and the hardware is pretty powerful.My biggest complaint would be the charge times for the controllers, they only last a few hours each. I feel like I'm always charging them and I'm really contemplating just keeping a plug next to my couch, which shouldn't be something I have to deal with. I've heard there's a new set of controllers coming out for the PRO system that have a lot longer life, so I may get one or two of those.Overall, if you're in the market for a console, you can't go wrong with the PS4 because there's so much to offer.

So far after a week with the PlayStation 4 I'm satisfied.  The hardware runs very well; things are much faster than previous generation in terms of game loading and navigating the system.  The UI is simple and basic; if you're looking for some crazy gorgeous presentation then you're going to have to wait at least until they start rolling out themes because it's pretty much generic in its looks.  If you're upgrading from the PS3 however you'll realize that it's a marked improvement over the XMB as things are a lot easier to find and react much faster.Loving the look of the games and the feel of the controller.  The controller is probably the biggest thing to talk about because it's an ENORMOUS improvement over the DualShock 3.  Feels good and responds very well.  It'll take some time getting used to not having Start and Select but you'll adapt.  Didn't get the camera so the light bar as it stands right now is only useful if you have two because instead of a number assignment it changes color to indicate what number player you are.  My only gripe would be that the battery seems to not last as long; it still lasts a good while but I feel the DS3 has a bit more life.Another big thing is that the network seems to move a lot faster.  PS3 used to basically limit your download speeds but that seems to be gone with the PS4.  Online gaming is great and they seem to really be pushing the social aspect really hard which is kind of unusual because again, if  you're coming from the PS3, you'll remember that people barely interacting in online gaming.  I love the party chat feature and matchmaking seems to be a bit better.  The share features are amazing; the Twitch streaming is great and it's cool to see so many people using it.  It actually makes for an easy way to check out a game and see if you'd like it or not without doing a lot of searching for gameplay.  My negative to this would be that it doesn't seem to queue downloads so even though they're faster if you have several games, demos or updates to download they run concurrently and that in effect will slow down the process.  Even with that though it's STILL faster than the PS3 network.So overall I like this system a lot.  Would I recommend you jump and get it now?  No, but that's because I never suggest that anyone buy a console at launch.  We've all seen the problems people have been having (the real ones at least, as sadly people have been making false claims), especially through Amazon.  While I do like them a lot i do have to call Amazon out on their packaging.  I know a lot of people feel like it's just a made up claim but it's actually true: Amazon did a pretty poor job of packaging the device.  Basically what they did was place the PS4 at the BOTTOM of the box, flush against the box's floor, and then dropped some air bags on top of it and sealed it.  If you know anything about shipping companies (especially UPS) you'll know that the drivers don't adhere to any warning labels; they will throw your box around without a care, so imagine them tossing your PS4 in the truck and how hard that bottom would hit the ground.  While I'm sure it's not the main cause of problems with the PS4 on here it's something that should be taken serious and complained about to Amazon because even with a working PS4 I'm not pleased by that at all.Still overall like I said it's a good console.  If you wait you'll most definitely end up with a better experience than us impatient people out of the box because eventually more of the features will be added, fixed, and developed into what they're suppose to be, but as it stands now it's a fun console and definitely worth the upgrade.

I was kind of nervous after reading some of the early reports of system failures right before the PS4 launch. I found one for sale at midnight and decided to order anyway since I've been wanting one of these for quite awhile. Man, I am so glad that I went through with the purchase. This is the best console I've ever owned. It has worked perfectly from the beginning and it turns out the launch failure rate for this product was around 4%. That is below the industry average for an electronics release of 5%. It truly feels like next gen with the speed of the OS and the look and performance of the games. I did debate for awhile on whether to get this or the new Xbox One. After hearing about the increase in power with the PS4 and that you are forced to buy the Kinect with the Xbox I decided to switch over to PS. I was a huge 360 fan the last generation. I am sure that I made the right decision. Most of the Xbox One games don't really have "next-gen" graphics and I don't want to have to give my Kinect voice commands. I think that is really pointless. Last generation I mostly preferred the 360 for the controller. I just didn't really like the PS3 Dualshock because I was just never comfortable with it. I have to tell you the new Dualshock 4 is amazing. Probably the best controller I have ever handled. I have big hands and I don't feel like it is way undersized. Overall I love the PS4 and am very satisfied with my purchase.

Simply amazing. This is everything we were promised, and more. I've been playing Battlefield 4 and AC IV Black Flag, and I have to say, it was money well spent.The console itself is a marvel, sleek and silent and impressive and simple all at once. The UI was overhauled and can now be accessed at any time, even while playing. Games can be suspended to do something else, and resumed without interruptions.The PSN now actually works, and the current game selection, while small, is great. PS+ actually gives you free access to a couple of them as well, so it's great that I already have a small library available (Resogun comes HIGHLY recommended!)The controller did the impossible and actually beat the 360 pad in terms of comfort. The thumbsticks were altered and are now shorter and thinner, with a concave top and grippy material. They are also a little further apart than the PS3. The triggers are also a vast improvement over the PS3, no longer sloping off the back of the controller, but more angled up, similiar again to the 360. This is GREAT news for shooter fans.Get this. Now. You need it. Get the second mortgage. Send your kids to your mother's house for a month. Take a vacation. Tell your significant other you'll be ignoring them a little.

The Good:--Console is practically silent when running--Controller is FAR better than the DualShock3 in the hand.  Touchpad works great.--Great console design--The UI is similar to the XMB on the PS3, but significantly improved.  Less crap to wade through than before, unless you WANT to wade through crap.--Game installs are fastThe Bad:--Graphics are good, but not mind-blowing.  It's just beginning though...they'll get better.--Controller battery life is not that great.  My PS3 controller is years old and still holds a charge longer than the PS4 controller.In all, I'm satisfied with the purchase.  No issues thus far with it...fired right up out of the box.  Had it now for a little over a week, though my play time has been light due to a heavy work schedule.  Have 3 games, Killzone (playing thru now), AC Black Flag and Battlefield 4 (both still unopened).  The lighting and particle effects in Killzone are strong, but the character models are still decidely last-gen.  I like how the LED on the back of the controller changes from green to yellow to red when your health goes down and then fades back to green when you heal.  Can't really see it when playing, but it's little details/flourishes like that that give me high hopes for future games.Playstation Plus is very nice...there is a lot of great content there, certainly enough to keep someone busy for a few weeks even if they don't have a game disc yet.  The "Live From PSN" feature is a lot of fun, which lets you watch other people streaming their games.  Talk about a GREAT way to research games and find out which ones you'd like (or hate)...good stuff.  I've already discovered that Knack looks pretty undesirable...maybe if I was more interested in button-mashing games.  On the other hand, the Lego/Marvel game looks pretty amusing.To those who received non-operable systems, my condolences, and hopefully Sony will get you up and running ASAP.  I can confirm that my unit was VERY poorly packaged...just a cardboard box slightly bigger than the PS4 box, NO PADDING OR CUSHIONING WHATSOEVER, and while it was taped shut, the outer box was not well-sealed and you could easily see what was inside through the "crack".  When I saw how it came, I was pretty sure it would be broken, but I guess I got lucky that it wasn't mishandled (intentionally?) by those hacks at UPS and it is working normally.  Amazon, get your act together when shipping electronics.Anyway...back to Killzone!
This is one mean System! I Can tell you the future looks good for this machine. It does not have the Graphics my one has YET! But I do see the potential!

I've been a gamer since the early '80's with extensive knowledge in the industry.  Knowledge or not, it's still just my opinion.There are many reviews and articles detailing the PS4's power in addition to comparative ones; so I won't touch that subject.  What I will chat about, is content and the controller.I purchase platforms depending on content and the PS4 is finally delivering its first exclusive game that interests me.  Infamous Second Son.  In fact, the only reason anyone should ever get a console is to play exclusive games.  Otherwise, PC's are the way to go (there are a couple of rare exceptions where the console choice was superior).If you're going to invest $400 of your hard earned cash, take a step back and think.  What games do I enjoy that aren't available on a PC? What first, second, and sometimes third party developer is most like going to produce a AAA title?At the time of this review, the following games have been confirmed exclusively for PS4:Driveclub, The Order: 1886, Killzone, Infamous, Uncharted, Knack, Deep Down, Earth Defense Force,Everybody's Gone to the Rapture, MLB, Secret Ponchos, Resogun, Rime, N++, Basement Crawl, Joysound Dive 2, Shadow of the Beast, Lily Bergamo, plus others.Sony owns extremely talented studios and several fantastic franchises.  Last generation, they brought us new IP's such as Heavy Rain, Uncharted, Little Big Planet, Infamous, The Last of US, Beyond Two Souls, ModNation, Flow, Flower, and Journey.  In addition, they own some great franchises.  Although we haven't seen some in years, there were several notable ones such as God of War, Twisted Metal, SOCOM, and Killzone.Make a list and compare, Do you want to play Nintendo's Zelda, Metroid, Mario, Donkey Kong, Kirby, Fire Emblem, X, Super Smash Bros, and Mario Kart? Or, Microsoft's Halo, Gears of War, and Killer Instinct? Perhaps it's God of War, Uncharted, Infamous, Little Big Planet, Heavy Rain, Killzone, and ModNation games that mostly peak your interest.Since Sony is a Japanese company, they're likely to get some superb role playing games.  Persona and Ni No Kuni come to mind.Controller: It's fantastic and definitely an improvement over its predecessor.  This time around, it includes a speaker, touch pad, and an interactive light.  Nintendo holds the crown when it comes to the D-pad but Sony is a close second.  The analog sticks are further apart which is an improvement.I don't care if a console has Netflix or Pandora.  The primary purpose is gaming and that's what my rating is based on.
Must buy for all gamers

My console works, I think!  After updating, the first thing I did was update the firmware, which went without a hitch.  Took a couple of tries to log into PSN for the first time; my guess is that PSN is bogged down from launch day.  Tried sharing a game on Twitch, which caused the system to hard freeze; couldn't force shutdown the PS4 using the power button, so had to unplug the system.  While installing Warframe, the system stopped responding a couple of times, again requiring a reboot; think it was related to resolution, as dropping down to 720p allowed the install to complete.  Still a bit unsure about how stable the system is; the system wouldn't wake up from standby, but I was able to force shutdown the system that time.  Hoping these are all just firmware or software bugs.Problems aside, I'm impressed with the console so far.  Haven't seen any signs of overheating so far; in fact it's quite the quiet console, compared to my Xbox 360.  The graphics in NBA 2K14 looks AMAZING.  There are times I feel that I'm watching a live game on TV instead of playing the game.  The Dualshock 4 feels great in my hand; it's not overly thick, and has a nice heft to it (that's the one thing I didn't like about the Dualshock 3).  Being able to stream all audio through headphones connected to the controller is perfect for late night gaming; I like how it uses a standard headphone port too, so I can use any headphones I want.  I love that Sony made the PS4's hard drive easily accessible and user-replaceable with a standard laptop hard drive; I plan to upgrade the 500GB drive to a 1TB fairly soon.I'm happy, but still cautious of the system stability.  Once more games come out and the bugs are worked out, I'll update the rating.
everything works as expected.

I first want to say that I am sorry to all those who have defective consoles. I know how frustrating that is and had to deal with it for a previous console launch. I won't name the console but it was a terrible experience. I wish you the best of luck and hope you get working consoles soon so we can play online together. I received my PS4 on 11/15 and was very concerned with the possiblity of a faulty console from what I had been hearing on various gaming websites. I had a minor issue when setting up my network connection. The system would keep asking if I wanted to use a proxy server over and over and then got stuck at "please wait..." I had to power off and power on again and reconfigure the network. I also can't switch network profiles. I took the console to a friends house and was unable to remove my previous wi-fi settings. I am confident these issues will be worked out in a future patch.I purchased Killzone, Knack, and Assassins Creed:Black Flag. Of the three, Black Flag is my favorite followed by Killzone. I don't really see a huge improvement in graphics but you can tell there is a difference. Launch titles never really deliver the amazing graphical experience that the console is capable of, at least in my past experience. The controller feels much heavier and is more responsive. The change to the L3 and R3 buttons alone make this better than the dualshock 3. The console is fairly quiet and gets louder when the fans kick on to cool the system. It runs a little warmer than I would prefer. Don't keep it on the carpet or in a closed space.Overall I am happy with my purchase and hope those who have broken systems get them fixed soon.

Having now had my PS4 for a month I've used quite a few of it's features. I've tested out it's voice commands (which have worked thus far, though admittedly not as advanced as Microsofts, it has the potential), I've played quite a few of the free games (a lot to be had from PS+), and now have about 4 games for the PS4. I'm impressed so far with how quickly the system can go about switching between tasks, and how crisp the games look especially when compared to the same game running on a PS3/XB360.Yes there aren't THAT many games to play at launch, but you buy a system for it's potential, not on what's on there currently, even if what is on it currently is quite fun.I do recommend it to anyone that has the interest (and the money).

The PS4 has many positives which greatly outweigh the negatives. As an early adopter you might find the launch lineup to be lackluster depending on your taste of games but that is subjective.Positives-Great Price-Games perform better on the PS4 compared to its competitors (XB1, Wii U)-DualShock 4 is a great controller (Headphone jack is a nice addition to it)-Form factor is great, it looks really nice-Party chat-Varied library of games-PS plus has good offerings considering that the console is fairly new-Remote play works great (May vary as it depends on connection speed at times)-Share button is easy to use with regards to capturing screenshots or recording video (Can also be used to stream game play via Twitch/Ustream)Negatives-No MP3 support yet-No suspend and resume yet-No way to organize games on the Dynamic Menu-Battery life on the DualShock 4 last approximately 6-7 hours

Great system for gamers with a good amount of upcoming console exclusives. It can play games of all sorts, ranging from adult/mature games to family friendly games to games that everybody can enjoy. With programs like Netflix, Youtube among others, there are multiple uses for the PS4 besides it just being a video game console. The ability to share achievements/accomplishments on twitter, facebook etc is an added bonus and streaming isn't all that hard if you choose to do that. I got the system about 2 months ago and still have not gotten around to every single detail of the PS4, there is just plenty to do.The PS4 also has great app support for your typical TV-watching type of apps (Netflix, Hulu, Amazon). I have a smart TV and used to use the apps built in to that to watch TV, but the experience is not only much faster on the PS4, it has some cool features that my TV doesn't like auto-play and adjustable subtitles. I use the apps more than I play games.I am very pleased with my purchase of a PS4 and got a very good deal with this. Me personally, I would say this is the best buy of the "Big 3" systems if you are choosing to get one. Sony has consistently provided good console exclusive after good console exclusive and given this is still a relatively new system for the most part, it is a good investment.Getting one of the best games in my opinion bundled with this system is like the cherry on top. The Last of Us is a brutal, violent, heart throbbing game that takes you on an adventure that you don't ever want to get off of. The game is not for everybody but survival horror fans and people who enjoy a compelling story will fall in love with this game. It comes inside as a free digital download so don't miss out on playing what is, you know, absolutely free.

Easiest console setup ever. The machine is quiet, powerful, and gets the job of playing games done beautifully.PROS:1. The new controller is so much better than the previous ones! Its comfortable, and I love the innovation of the touchpad on the front, it works like a button when pressed down as well.2. Its quiet, no Xbox 360 levels of turbine power involved.3. Its got most video streaming services available out of the box with a quick download.4. Most of the games available run in native 1080p, which means much prettier games!5. The audio out on the controller is an awesome little feature! I never realized how nice this would be when sharing the room with my girlfriend, I just pop in my iphone earbuds and play away.6. Twitch streaming is awesome! Admittedly unless you're playing something you're very good at or competing people won't watch your stream.CONS:1. Controller battery life. Its a little short. Had to put it on to charge every day before I went to bed.2. Console seems to get hot, but no worse than my old 360 or PS3, but you should keep in mind when putting it in your entertainment center. Recently I picked up a ps4, as well as an xbox one. Since I'm a technology junkie, and buy just about every console that comes out- minus Nintendo .  As for the ps4, really nice build quality, console is small, sleek, quiet , and about 50% more powerful than the xbox . Gpu is 40% prior to ms announcing they reserve 10% for the kinect , and recently we discovered that the CPU is actually more powerful on ps4, as well.  When you discuss memory, ps4 is using 8gb of the new gddr5 memory, where as xbox one is using 8gb, of much slower DDR3 memory. What this means is the ps4 can transfer data to gpu/ CPU at 176gbps, where as xbox one is at 68gbps. Xbox one tries to close this gap by using 1/3 of gb (.32 to be exact ) of esram which allows data transfer at 102gbps, but keep in mind this is .32gb, so of the whole 8gb, this is only 1/3 of 1gb. These are just a few examples as to why ps 4 is running most games at 1080p, and quite a few of these same games run at 720p on xbox one . As for the ps4, the new GUI is blazing fast . I had a ps3, and it's lightning fast in comparison . Sony has really upped their game with this system , I also feel that sony is closing the gap with their online structure. Psn is really becoming a good service . I don't want this to seem like I don't like my xbox one, cause it's a good system as well, I think Microsoft is just much for focused on a media box than a game system . Should be interesting to see how the next couple years shake out.

It's hard to find an objective review on this system with the usual console wars and fun-blocking going on but I'm going to give it to you straight from someone who has objectively looked at all of the negative reviews, rumors, and played at least 4 games (Knack, Lego Marvel Super Heroes, Assassin's Creed 4 and Skylanders Swap Force).PROS:-Small and sleek design. It fits vertically in the only space I had for it on my entertainment center ( a 3 inch wide ledge beside the TV.-Game discs load onto HDD for overall faster loading times.-Aside from some loading noises on start-up I never hear a peep out of it even after hours of gaming.-Games look and play absolutely beautifully!  Not a glitch or lag or issue in sight.-SHARE button!  Omg, if I ever get a glitch, I am going to LOVE having this to capture the fun!-the controller is PERFECT.  The material, the joystick grooves, the touch pad, all of it feels great.  I was worried it would be too big (I like smaller grips since I have small hands) but it is SO comfortable and only a tad bit wider than the DualShock 3.  This is a lightweight beauty made for long hours!  Touch pad complaints are that the click is generic (?); totally not seeing where that comes from.-power and eject buttons are terrific too.  No more holding it, hoping it's the right spot or searching for the damn thing.  Once you know where it is (and I appreciate the subtlety) you could find it in the dark.CONS:-The bad reviews!  I have seen everything from HDMI port malfunctions to blue screen (from faulty HDDs or update fixes, etc). and after the research, I see most of them are from pre-launch systems or just regular DOAs.  People, computers can come DOA; it's a downside to technology and it's why limited warranties are standard.  Merchants honor replacements or merchandisers will offer repairs-- it doesn't make that company dishonest and it's not a new concept.  That being said, read up on reviews and weigh the risks.  Make sure you buy from trusted sources and stop blaming companies for expected issues.-I still wish launch systems always bundled two controllers, but that's an old-school gripe.I should probably have more cons directly related to the system, but honestly, I have found nothing bad about the PS4 so far.  Launch systems have always been a shaky affair but this one has really eased my mind.  This is a gamer's console, without a doubt, and I am a single-player kind of gamer so this is a dream.  I'm sure the online aspects are terrific but that's not my scene.  All I know is that I am absolutely satisfied with my first week of experience with the PS4 and it 100% fits my needs.  The interface is beautiful, the loading and menus are really easy to get used to, the games run seamlessly and look spectacular.  I couldn't ask for more in a system.
Good product so far. Waiting to buy a console exclusive to see its full potential though. So far so good.

Amazing system right out of the box. Best launch titles I've experienced in a long time, and a beautiful piece of hardware. Have been playing all weekend (since launch), including Knack, Killzone, Assassin's Creed, Resogun, and more. All of them are stunning.The games that stand out for me in particular are Knack and Resogun - both are very addictive and highly polished. Knack feels like playing a Dreamworks movie, and the hop-in co-op feature really puts that extra DualShock 4 controller I bought to good use. I am really hoping to get into Killzone and Assassin's Creed more (Killzone is especially impressive), but I also just received my Need for Speed Rivals pre-order, so I suspect I will find myself split.Speaking of the DS4 - it is a remarkable improvement to the PlayStation controller line. My fiance is incredibly impressed by how comfortable it is, and the fact that we both agree - even me with my large mitts - shows how much effort was put into the ergonomics of the controller. The weight and size feels perfect, and really does the system as a whole justice. One really neat feature, that gets glanced over in some reviews, is the ability to plug any standard headphones into the controller and pump all of the system audio through the controller, wirelessly. No delay, either. I've been using my iPhone earpods (later version), and the quality is great. Microphone works well too. When not using the headphones, the speaker on the controller adds a layer of depth to games like Knack and Resogun that is a real treat.One really awesome feature that we didn't realize from all of the pre-release reviews is that each controller can be assigned to a user, and that user can be connected to a PSN account. Whenever you turn on a controller, it asks "who's using this controller?". Which ever account you pick, that person will log in. In a game like Knack, both me and my roommate have our own PSN accounts and are both logged in. Depending on which controller is used to launch the game, that user is the primary player and is playing to earn trophies on their profile. Each user, though, has their own "home screen", meaning at any time I can press the PS button on the controller and go to MY home screen, see my friends, change my settings, etc. During this time my roommate can't interact with the screen - it's my home screen after all. We can hop back into the game quickly, or he can press the PS button on his controller and go into his homescreen, where he gets to interact with his friends, change his settings, etc. Because we're both logged in, the status of both of our accounts is "Playing Knack". It's a fantastic way to utilize the account system and tie it directly with a controller. If we're playing with his game save, and he is earning trophies for his account, as soon as he wants to stop, he can end the game and put his controller down and I can go to my homescreen with the PS button and launch a new game. I am instantly using my account and earning trophies for me, now, without having to log out of the system first or changing which controller is "Controller 1". It is one of the stand out features of the system for us.Owning a Vita, the remote play has been excellent. There isn't much use for the second screen option yet, but I believe there will be soon. Using the PS App on my iPhone has been excellent, too. Using my phone to type is much easier than the controller, and really rounds out the ecosystem. If you have a PlayStation console, you definitely want the PS App. Using it to add and message friends is a timesaver.Hoping to be a clairvoyant voice among the angry mob - my system has experienced ZERO issues, and neither have my friends (old and new, IRL and online). Set up was a breeze, update was painless, and the time it took from opening the box to playing a game was literately minutes. Games download and install insanely quick - as someone who has been 'ok' with the PS3s tortoise-like crawl, the PS4 is like going from dial-up to Fiber. I cannot reiterate enough how quick and easy this system is to get running.
Best way to start the new year, I love my PS4.  It is very powerful and the new controller is better then the PS3 version.

Let me say that this is my second PS4.  I bought one for Xmas but it was DOA.  I sent it back to Amazon and waited a bit before I bought another one, from Amazon.  I was going to give it 4 stars because of the first one, but I understand that every now and then a product will have an issue or two, especially a new one.With that said, this console was super easy to get up and running.  It does take a bit long to load a game, but so does my Xbox One, and I only load games once so that is no big deal.  The graphics are very, very good, extremely sharp.  The controller feels good in my hands, and the interface is simple, fast and clean.  The console is quiet and does not heat up much during use.I'm not a huge baseball fan, but I love playing MLB on this console, the graphics are off the chart good.  I also like the overall design of the console.  It is slim, with no power brick and thus easier to make room for as opposed to my Xbox One.  All in all, a great console and I am looking forward to the new games that will be available shortly for the PS4.On a side note, as you can tell I also own the Xbox One, which I also got for Xmas.  Both consoles are hooked to my big screen Samsung TV, as well as (via HDMI hub/switch) my new LG 34UM95.....which I absolutely love by the way.  To this day, I really do not know which console I like more.  Some days I use the PS4 and other days its the Xbox One.  I am not a "fanboy" of either, in fact I did not even know what the term meant until I started reading reviews for these consoles.  I like the simplicity and cleanness of the PS4 interface.  I like the extra functionality of the Xbox One, that goes beyond gaming.  I like them both, and glad I have them both.

I am in love with this console.The graphics are amazing.  I love the look of the games on this system.  The sound is impeccable.  We run it off a 7.1 surround system, and I've had moments where a twig will snap behind me, or a beast will roar off to the left.  It is a bit more precise that I'm used to in how it handles locating sound between speakers, by firing both off but not at the same volume.  I really love that.The controller is so comfortable.  I had some problems early on with the rubber coming off, but each time Sony was great about quickly replacing the controller.  The audio jack on the controller means even the most basic headset can be effectively wireless for gaming.  I did not think I would like the touchpad, but now I love it.  It has an accelerometer, so for Infamous: Second Son, when you are using the controller like a can of spray paint, you have to turn it sideways and shake it.  And the embedded speakers are such, it sounds like a can of spray paint being shaken.  The PS3 controller always bothered me a little that it is too easy to inadvertently push down the left thumbpad (so it thinks you hit L3) when you are trying to run around.  I've yet to encounter that problem with this one, not even doing the various rundown sections of Assassin's Creed: Black Flag.Sharing in-game video is quick and easy.  It works so well, and so fast.  I didn't think I would use that, but it turns out I kind of like sharing awesome moments on Facebook.  I'm very much a solo gamer, and the library for that is still very impressive.If you have PlayStation Plus, your games are backed up online.  When I upgraded the hard drive, which is ridiculously simple, I just redownloaded my games, already in progress.  It picked up where it left out without a hitch.For stability, for elegance, for performance, and most importantly, for incredible game play, I give the PS4 five stars.

This is amazing, all of my friends love going to my house and playing it.ProsIt's fast, and it has amazing graphicsGames run fluidlyFast startupChat is awesomeVideo recording is great and there's a editing software on it alsoConsIt freezes once in a whileShare play doesn't work on mine very wellBrowsing in the browser could be betterDifficult to find how to share voice on videosThis would make a great gift for any age above 8It's fun and I'd rate it a 9/10. Wish it wouldn't collect as much dust and fingerprints. It doesn't annoy me too much though. It scratches easily too. They've also fixed the controller buttons so they won't peel and that's awesome.

First thing you notice is just how small it is. It's smaller than any version of the PS3 (even the "super slim" model) ever made, and slides into a home theater stack far more easily.The back has a standard ports: HDMI, Ethernet, optical audio out, and a proprietary socket for the optional PlayStation Camera. All you need are two cables — power and HDMI. VERY EASY!Controller: Easy to hold, light weight, USB powered... best controller I've held.Start screen: Easy to navigate - a good update from the PS3. The only flaw is the web browser. Sony just can't seem to get this right. Still, the Netflix app is solid.  Really though, who browses the web on their PS4?!Games: As mentioned above, the browser is not good, but you're not buying this to browse the web.  Simply put - the games look amazing.  Full 1080p - better than anything I've seen. I won't go into reviewing the games - a picture is worth a thousand words.Summary - If you want the best gaming platform out there - this is for you.  You may also want to upgrade your TV to get the full experience.

I am a multi-console owner who also has a Xbox One (see my profile for Xbox One review). I was a huge supporter of the PS3/360/Wii and have the Wii U. I have to say of all 3 this is my favorite console of the next gen consoles. Why is that? It is simple in its user interface. It improves on the extended media bar by making adding another layer on top of it. Its like one media bar on top of the other. There is a lot of social aspects added into it that track your friends progress, not just by trophies but my special accomplishments and what they are watching. The trophies are now more special by giving an indication how rare they are. A new aspect is streaming your game live or making clips to post for others to see. It is easy to use and has a sleek simple interface.The controller is easily the most important aspect of the system. I am proud to see this is my favorite controller if this generation. It is very sturdy in the whole design, especially the triggers and the analog sticks. They are extremely tight which makes them feel they will last a long time. I was surprised how loose the PS3's analog sticks are in comparison and even compared to the Xbox One's controller. The speaker on the controller is loud and clear, more so than speaker in the wii-mote. The touch pad works smoothly and nice in games like Killzone: Shadow Fall.Now if anyone doesn't know, the PS4 is the most powerful console. It doesn't mean all games will look better than the competition but majority will. It was built with a lot of developer input and designed to get away from the difficult ridiculous design of past Playstation development tools which hampered it from being able to have the best version of games and not having enough RAM to compete to have the same quality of titles in games such as Fallout 3 and Skyrim. Sony has answered this with DDR5. It also has some of the leading developers such as Naughty Dog, Media Molecule, Sony Santa Monica, Quantum Dreams, and Sucker Punch.If you want the most powerful system, a greatly improved controller for FPS games. A console that innovates and takes rich with new IPs such as Flower, Journey, Unfinished Swan, and the LittleBIGPlanet than Sony is the choice who takes the lead and doing so with new games like Octodad, Rosogun (the best next gen game right now), and a lot of other indies but also one who provides a trend of bringing new big AAA experiences such as The Last of Us, Infamous, Uncharted, than the PS4 is a good choice. That trend is continuing with new games such as The Order: 1886 and old ones such as Uncharted 4 and Infamous: Second Son.Games Played (and own) on PS4:ResogunBattlefield 4 (beaten)Killzone: Shadow Fall (beaten)Assassin's Creed: Black Flag

Received my PS4 on Friday and so far it's all been good. It's great to finally have a console capable of 1080p. The new interface is solid, I really like the whats new addition so I can see what my friends have done. PSN is still a little limited, but come on, it's a launch, many things are NEVER available at launch. Just like consoles before it, it should have most of its features live in a year. I purchased it mainly to have the upgraded multiplats now, and know that in the future great games will be coming, Sony has great first party studios. Killzone is solid and Infamous is coming in spring. As far as first party shows, look at the PS2 and PS3, sony has never failed at delivering quality First Party games.And another note, my PS4 has been working fine, been playing BF4, Resogun and Ghosts all weekend and have clocked 15+ hours on it. It has already outlived my Launch PS3 and 360 consoles. Also it's nice to see party chat finally come to PSN, and it's also great that you get Resogun for free if you subscribe to PSN+, which I already had anyway.I'm reviewing this on based a Launch system, but also on what will eventually turn into a great console as the future unfolds with time. I'm very excited to see what the future holds.

First I must give a shout out to Amazon for keeping my reservation for the PS4. I was due to have my PS4 delivered to me on Friday 11/15/13. They attempted to charge my card on Thursday 11/14/13 but I did not get paid (Direct Deposit) until Midnight leading into Friday. They could have easily canceled my reservation and said good luck on getting a PS4 now or anytime soon. Amazon sent me an email letting me know that they tried to make the transaction go through but they couldn’t. They told me I had 3 days to pay for the item or my order would be canceled. Fortunately I didn’t even need the 3 days, my transaction went through on Friday and they shipped it out Friday. I would have received it Saturday but I was getting my PS4 delivered to my job (Nope I’m not trusting this to get delivered at my house while no one is there) and my job is closed on the weekends. So I did get it Monday 11/18/13. So I was able to live for 2 more days. So again, big ups to AMAZON for their customer service.The PS4 games on this console is strikingly beautiful. There is a major decrease in loading time when it comes to playing games, streaming Netflix, or Hulu, ect versus the PS3. They do come with an earpiece that looks a little on the cheap side but you can hear your on-line buddies just fine.  They do have the option of putting your PS4 in a “very low” power mode, and during this time you can have your controller attached charging up for the next time you play. I love the freebee games they give you (When you sign up for Play station Plus). Make sure you download “RESOGUN” soooooooo freakin awesome.!!!!!

Overall it's a good system and would recommend to all my friends. I only have 3 games but so far I enjoy this new system.  Definitely an upgrade from the PS3

My brother had gone for New Jerssy for a week(I'm in India), so I planned to order this through Amazon so that he can bring it back to India.  My review would be helpful for those Indians( or Asians) who would like to buy PS4 from States. Becuase here in India it costs double the cost that of in US.I ordered this on Saturday evening 4pm(India time), i.e saturday morning 6.30am in NJ (my shipping address).The package was delivered to my brothers office Monday morning around 11am. That was very quick. I was worried they will take like4-5 days so my brother would  miss the package. But yeah he got in time and he took a picture and sent me through whatsapp. It was well packed.  He did unboxing in his hotel room and I,m not sure if they added any bubblewraps or something.I was worried about following things,1) If I get a DOA PS4, then all I can do is make a youtube video on break your PS4 or drop your PS4 or something. since Sony has told that warranty would be void if we import PS4 from US. (although they are ready to replace PS4 with another $399)2) Power statistics. India has 240v/50Hz , and US is 120v, 60Hz.3)Indian Customs, who are waiting for bribes from international travels who bring electronic items and golds.Solutions,1) Thankfull, My PS4 turned on perfectly and day1 update was perfect  and everything went reall well. I read  that Amazon had lot of broken PS4, but mine was a success story. I could not find any faults.2)I saw a youtube video that eventhough the USA Ps4 power number is written 120 only, it still works with asian powers.So with name of God I hooked the power and it was fine. I did not need a step down trasformer or something.3) My bro packed it in luggage bag and somehow he escaped the customs!! so around 100-200 USD save there .I bought a APC UPS for my PS4 and it works great with it, I have been playing watchdogs for quiet and while and I love the performance.I'm very very happy with the product and I love it. Works like Magic. I saved around $300 by purchasing it from Amazon USA.

I purchased this console in November of 2014 to play Dragon Age Inquisition. I have to say that in the few years that I've been gaming, I have never used such a great console. It's really easy to set up (in my opinion), and the home screen is pretty sleek looking. The only bad thing I can really say about it is that dust can collect more easily than my PS3. I think I'll have to invest in a PS4 stand to help with that. The only real downside to this console is the selection of games. Right now I own all of 2-3 games on the console. I do look forward to new games being released.

This system was a gift for my husband and he was totally surprised and shocked when I got it for him. We have both played a few games on it and I enjoy it just as much as he does. A wonderful and clean system that provided a wonderful gaming experience. (:

I was a little worried with the BLOD but my system worked right out of the box. I had also bought one for a co-worker and no problems there. The thing I like the best with the new system is the seamless UI as it is super fast now and you can just press the playstation button to go out of a game into the main menu or between different loaded games. I also love that you can play the game as soon as you put in the disc without little to no loading times as the game loads in the background as you play it. I haven't tried the social functions like streaming your gameplay yet but I hear it works great. I hope they allow for it to be done to Youtube and not just facebook as I don't have an account there. Unfortunately the entertainment functions are limited no CD, MP3's and DLNA at this time. It doesn't even recognize my flash drive. Sony is supposeto patch these later on(well no confirmation on DLNA) as well as being able to use my Pulse headset. I hope they do this in the next few months as these should be basic functions.Overall if you want a game machine I would get the PS4 due to better GPU and CPU than other consoles in the market combined with the social functions and of course top rated exclusive games that will be coming in the next year from Sucker Punch and Naughy Dog. I have no regrets in this purchase and would recommend this console over the others for people trying to move up to the next generation of gaming.

One thing Im not sure people mentioned is their networking account system. Coming from Xbox, most games wouldn't let you play with others on different accounts (family/friends) online on the same xbox unless they have Xbox live or they use guest. I know for some the guest makes you feel less of a part of the community, no individuality but rather the butt buddy of another.  Sony is similar with their paying system for pan+ vs xbl, except if one person has the psn+ (PlayStation network plus) on their main system, then anybody can use their account on that system and gain the online gameplay priveliges and most benifits as if they had psn. By this I dont mean only when the other person is logged in, but even if the psn+ owner is off.  That made me respect sony and enjoy my PlayStation all the more. I felt they weren't only out to eat my pockets but also looking to give what I'm paying for. I recommend
